PETITION.TITLE: Privacy Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
The Hawke Labor Government's Privacy Amendment Bill concerning Credit Reference Reporting will

Reject Labor Government's Privacy Amendment Bill to enable businesses to have access to credit information they require to make sensible commercial decisions.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

(1) are opposed to the holding of an Arms Bazaar, AIDEX '89, at the National Exhibition Centre in Canberra on 28-30 November 1989

That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.

That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Minister representing the Prime Minister and Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of the continuing campaign of industrial action by the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union in Victorian meatworks, which is estimated to have cost the beef industry in that State close to $50m since the end of May? Is he further aware that Deputy President Riordan, in a judgment on 13 November, described as `reprehensible' the stoppages which have continued after the insertion of a bans clause?
—This is the same Riordan whom you attacked in the pharmacy case.

—This is the same Riordan who I think would not have any reputation as being hard on the trade unions. Given that the Government, through former Minister Willis, has said that the bans clause procedures are moribund, and given the strong backing of the Government for the common law actions against the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, would the Government similarly strongly support the use of common law against this union which continues to defy the decisions and directions of the Industrial Relations Commission?

—Before I could answer the last part of Senator Chaney's question, I would have to see what action the employers contemplated in the circumstances because they would be the parties which would involve themselves in any action of that kind.
—But you would support them if they did.

—I would make no prior judgment about it. I would wait and see what circumstances emerged. Having said that, I do have a passing knowledge of the dispute to which Senator Chaney refers. No doubt, it is extraordinarily damaging to the meat industry in Victoria. Not only did Deputy President Riordan have something to say about this, but a Full Bench of the Industrial Relations Commission handed down a decision which apparently has not been accepted by the parties, and by the union in particular. I apologise. I think that relates partly to Queensland and partly to Victoria. The industrial action in Victoria has been going on for some time. Riordan inserted a bans clause on 1 November. I accept Senator Chaney's suggestion that no action has been taken in respect of that at this stage. I will try to obtain further information from the Minister.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I welcome the Minister's final comment that he will seek further information. I ask the Minister to examine the history of these rolling strikes; to examine the defiance of the Industrial Relations Commission, which is part of the pattern of behaviour; to examine the destruction not merely of private business but of Australia's export trade; and to advise the Senate whether in those circumstances, where there is clear defiance of the Commission, the Government would support the use of common law actions by employers who have received absolutely no satisfaction from the other processes which are available to them.
—I will address those questions to the Minister, together with Senator Chaney's earlier question.

—I ask the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs whether his attention has been drawn to press reports of the comments of the Western Australian Minister of Police, Mr Ian Taylor, regarding a bikie gang war in Western Australia. What action does the Minister intend to take in regard to this matter?
—I thought we had this question yesterday.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right. This is `Bikie Wars II'. I did notice the comments of Mr Taylor from Western Australia. It is a typical case of a provincial Minister dumping all responsibility where it does not belong, that is, back to the Federal Government. If Mr Taylor had the slightest knowledge at all of our deportation laws, he would know that I am hardly likely to start deporting victims of crime. What I have consistently said is that if a criminal act has occurred and a conviction occurs, and the criminal act involves violence, I will have no hesitation at all in deporting those particular individuals. But I cannot just willy nilly pull out of the hospital some bloke who has been shot and say to him, `You are a victim of a bikie war. I am sending you home'. I would have thought that the major job in Western Australia was for the police to catch the perpetrators and prosecute them.

ANSWER.PARA: The secondary issue, however, is serious, in as much as it is rumoured that a thousand of the victims' friends from New Zealand are going to arrive over here in some way and start a major brawl. We have contacted the New Zealand police and obtained the names of at least 1,000 of the New Zealand bikie gang, and we will use that list to make sure when people arrive in this country that they are not coming here for the wrong purpose. There is a section under the Act which allows us to return them to New Zealand straightaway. But I am not about to stop everyone who has a tattoo or a leather jacket getting off QF1 and say, `You can't arrive here'. The trans-Tasman agreement is a little more serious than that, I would believe.

This is a little unfortunate in that I thought we had finally started to bury some of the myths surrounding New Zealand immigrants to this country. This year 27,000 New Zealanders will permanently settle in Australia. All our surveys show that they are younger, more skilled and less prone to criminal activity for the age group than the Australian average, and the old image of the Bondi New Zealand dole bludger has well and truly been put to rest. The unemployment rate of New Zealand born citizens in this country is below the Australian average and, especially considering their age range, that is even more surprising, and the same with criminal activity.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a real problem when the Minister speaks in that way.

—Senator Chaney should not distract me; I was just about to wind up. The honourable senator wants a short answer and I was just about to wind up. Criminality for that age group is again well below the Australian average. I hope that intemperate remarks made by someone looking to blame someone else in Western Australia do not again spark an anti-New Zealand feeling in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and Treasurer. I ask whether the Minister agrees with Premier Bannon's comment on the Hawke Government, and I quote:

QUESTION.PARA: I think it would be in Australia's interest if they could get their act together.

Governments can always do better than they sometimes do, and there is always a wish to do that. In so far as there having to be change as stated by Premier Bannon, I do not know to what aspect of Government policy he is referring but I will try to follow that up.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Is the Minister, by giving a very brief answer-in fact, a non-answer-to the question, relating to a serious matter before the people of South Australia at the moment, saying that he is satisfied with interest rates which are double those of many comparable countries, inflation which is double that of the average of the seven major industrial countries, the highest current account deficit relative to gross domestic product (GDP) of any Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development country and declining real wages in five out of the seven years of Labor's term in office? Is the Minister asking the people of Australia to believe that despite this dismal record of failure there is no need to change the Government's economic strategy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that. It was a very deft supplementary question that the honourable senator cobbled together, and I shall comment on various parts of it. Certainly, I am not happy with the high interest rates which currently prevail in Australia. As the honourable senator knows, I have answered questions about that matter almost every day in the Senate for some weeks now, and I do not propose to repeat the answer. As to the comment that the inflation rate is double that of our trading partners, that is partly true in respect of some of our trading partners but it is not true in respect of others. But the rate of inflation in Australia is too high.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the current account deficit as a proportion of gross domestic product is concerned, I am not satisfied with that, but I think the current account deficit as a proportion of GDP is exactly the same as when the Liberal-National Government went out of office in 1982. As for wages, yes, it is true that there has been a lowering of real wages for adult males in Australia during the period of this Government. On the other hand, household disposable income has increased. The only year in which household disposable income declined by more than a very modest sum was in 1982, the last year of the coalition Government. I do not think the honourable senator mentioned the question of employment, but the Government is very satisfied with the employment growth which has taken place in this country and which has contributed to rising per capita household incomes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade relates to two rather contradictory public statements issued by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock. Is the Government guilty of `timidity and equivocation', as Mr Peacock claims, in not to date taking legal action against Pol Pot in the International Court of Justice? Is Mr Peacock's recent conversion to this litigation proposal a rather desperate attempt by him to gain the high moral ground he had apparently abandoned, at least to my confusion, as recently as 15 November when he issued a press release proposing that the Khmer Rouge be part of an interim Cambodian Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Peacock, in a rather long and fierce press release which he issued yesterday, criticised the Government for `timidity', `passivity', and `equivocating and refusing to take a lead' in initiating action against Pol Pot, and those who were his deputies in the 1975-79 period, in the International Court of Justice (ICJ) under the Genocide Convention. It was, of course, the Labor Government, through Mr Hayden, that first internationally raised the possibility, in 1986, of establishing an appropriate international tribunal to determine the culpability of the Pol Pot leadership.

ANSWER.PARA: We continue to regard this proposal as an attractive one and are continuing to explore ways of implementing it. We do so not only because properly documented findings of guilt by a credible international tribunal would no doubt have a major impact on international public opinion, but also because it might help to define with more precision the identities of those who should under no circumstances be allowed to play a role in the future of any Cambodian administration -and, as such, would address one of the numerous practical problems that need to be addressed before free elections can be held.

However, if the proposal is to be implemented, a practical way of doing so must be found. It is the present judgment of the Government, based on detailed consideration in 1986 and subsequently by our own international lawyers, that, contrary to Mr Peacock's assertion, there are formidable procedural and jurisdictional obstacles standing in the way of the initiation of an action by Australia against Pol Pot and his deputies in the International Court of Justice. That is why Mr Hayden did not put the proposal forward in those terms and why it has not been pursued in the International Court since then.

Let me spell out the position a little further, Mr President. While it is true that cases heard by the ICJ involve states, rather than governments, bringing actions against each other, and while both Australia and Cambodia are states-parties to the Genocide Convention, for all practical purposes litigation has to take place between governments which are in effective control of the states in question. Even if the court were prepared to regard an action in the present matter as properly initiated against the Coalition Government of Democratic Cambodia (CGDK), which is only in effective control of the seat in the United Nations and not anything else in Cambodia, rather than the current Hun Sen administration on the ground in Phnom Penh, the Court, nonetheless, has made clear that it will pronounce judgment-and I quote from a 1960s case which is still, I believe, good law-`only in connection with concrete cases where there exists at the time of the adjudication an actual controversy involving a conflict of legal interests between the parties'. It will be remembered, for example, that in the French nuclear test case the court held that it would not consider Australia's claim for a declaration, given that France had undertaken not to conduct any more atmospheric tests.

So there is a very real question, accordingly, as to whether the court would accept jurisdiction where what would be involved, on Mr Peacock's idea, is Australia seeking to initiate an action against a regime which is no longer in effective control of the state of Cambodia, in relation to events more than 10 years old. There is, moreover, a very real political, or perhaps I should preferably say `diplomatic', problem in the present environment for Australia, which has refused to give any formal recognition to the Pol Pot regime as the legitimate government of the state of Cambodia, in effect doing so-if only for the formal purposes of this litigation.

However, having said that, if Mr Peacock does have access to what he describes as `extensive international legal analysis' by reputable international lawyers credibly establishing that the various legal concerns I have expressed are ill-founded, and credibly establishing that there are no serious practical obstacles standing in the way of initiation of proceedings, I would be very glad if he would make that material available. Certainly, the Government would give very serious consideration to pursuing such a case if we genuinely thought it would not be rejected by the Court, just as we would, of course, be prepared to support any other government which was willing and proved able to initiate such proceedings itself. Until such a case is established and not just asserted, it is proper to regard Mr Peacock's contribution to this debate-whether or not it was an attempt, as Senator Collins says, to recapture the high moral ground-as just another example of the politics of the grand empty gesture which he has made peculiarly his own.

I finish by saying that in the absence of the availability of the ICJ there are simply no other international courts or tribunals which could possibly play a relevant role. A more realistic approach to the question of determining Pol Pot's guilt has always seemed to the Government to be the establishment-preferably by multilateral international agreement but, failing that, on some ad hoc basis-of an essentially informal tribunal of senior, respected, international legal figures. There would be no authority in this context to compel anyone's presence or to apply sanctions of any kind, or even make a declaratory judgment of the weight that a judgment of that kind would have in the International Court. Nonetheless, presumably, some effective exercise in weighting and balancing the available evidence would possibly be undertaken.

Mr Hayden raised this possibility when discussing the issue internationally, as he did quite extensively after he first raised it at the Association of South East Asian Nations post-ministerial conference in 1986. At the time he was forced to conclude that there was not sufficient international support in practice to proceed with that proposal. It may be that in the present environment there would be more such support, and I will certainly take the opportunity to discuss the question in the course of my contacts with foreign ministerial and other relevant figures over the next few months.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I draw the Minister's attention to his answer to my question on 24 October concerning a proposed development on the North Entrance Peninsula on the central coast of New South Wales, and Australia's international agreements with Japan and China relating to migratory and wetlands birds. I ask: firstly, has the Minister received any response from the New South Wales Government to his letters concerning the North Entrance Peninsula? If so, what was the nature of that response? Secondly, will the Minister raise the matter within the Council of Conservation Ministers, which is the forum designated to consider such transfers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the second question on this matter from Senator McLean, who is obviously showing quite an interest in it. I mentioned, when I was asked the first time, that I had written to the New South Wales Government and I have now received a response from Mr Hay, the Minister for Local Government and Planning in that Government. In his response, Mr Hay stated that the Wyong Shire Council referred a draft local environment plan to his Department so that a report could be prepared and, based on that report, the Minister would decide whether to approve the proposed rezoning of part of the North Entrance Peninsula to permit a tourist facility and golf course.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Hay tells me that a revised plan has been submitted in which this proposed tourist facility does not involve lake foreshore areas or the dredging or destruction of estuarine and wetland areas. Wyong Council has deferred its consideration of plans which could affect the lake foreshore and the beach frontage. I have received Mr Hay's assurance that he will have regard to the issues I have raised, in particular the migratory birds agreement, when he looks at zoning and future development of the peninsula.

With regard to the second part of the question, the overall responsibility for the coordination role for the operation of that migratory birds agreement is via a working group of the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers (CONCOM). However, the responsibility for any specific site remains the responsibility of State legislation and that is a matter for State consideration. Mr Hay has indicated that he accepts the responsibility of the New South Wales Government to adhere to the principles of the migratory birds agreement. I only hope that his Government lives up to that responsibility, but I must say that I am encouraged by his response and at this stage I see no need to raise the matter with CONCOM.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and is drawn sharply into focus following the claim this morning by a Colombian drug trafficking group that it was responsible for the mid-air explosion of an airliner belonging to Avianca Airlines, which resulted in the death of all 107 people on board. Can the Minister inform the Senate of what Australia is doing to help to prevent this sort of violence and, by extension, to reduce the potential for Australia to become a market for the cocaine cartels of Colombia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Jones for his question. I am sure that all honourable senators will be horrified at the apparently very violent and savage act of the drug barons of Colombia in, as they have claimed, bringing about the explosion of an aircraft with the loss of 107 innocent lives. I have mentioned in this chamber before some terrible statistics, taken from Time magazine, of drug related murders in Colombia over the past seven years-108 politicians, 157 judges, 17 journalists, 1,536 policemen, 3,491 narcotics officers, 408 soldiers, 118 guerrillas, 3,100 civilians-a total of 8,935 persons. What is clear is that the drug barons have declared war on their people and, as we know, they have also targeted Australia, or Australians, as a marketplace where they can generate cash flow to fund these nefarious murders and terrorist activities.

ANSWER.PARA: In the light of that, I am pleased that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and I have been able to announce today that we will be helping to fund a sophisticated computer project in Colombia as a practical means of helping to fight the South American drug scourge. Indeed, this aid project will be co-funded by Australia and the Netherlands, with an Australian contribution of $150,000, operated under the banner of the United Nations Fund for Drug Abuse Control. This special aid project will allow the operation of a computer databank project with combined law enforcement and preventative education objectives and will be implemented by the Colombian national council on narcotics drugs.

Over the years the Australian Government has had some experience in the provision to overseas countries of computer assisted methods of combating drug trafficking. In Thailand, under the auspices of the Office of the Narcotics Control Board, Australia has for some years been providing assistance to that agency, particularly in relation to its computer projects. That assistance has been very well received. Of course, such assistance not only is of benefit to the country concerned but, in the case of Thailand, it helps Australia as the war lords of the Golden Triangle traffic heroin into Australia. One hopes that what we do in Colombia will also help to stem the tide of cocaine which is very clearly being targeted on Australia. The Government and the peoples of Colombia have obviously been resisting this murderous activity of the drug barons in a way which is full of courage. But they need every assistance possible. I believe the international community is standing in solidarity with the Colombian people and their elected government and I believe that this enterprise, this project being undertaken by Australia with the very ready and willing cooperation of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, will stand as a very real symbol of the way in which the Australian people are standing with those in Colombia who are obviously the target of these terrible terrorist activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and I refer him to his answer on 6 September on allegations of harassment by People's Republic of China officials of PRC nationals. I remind the Minister of articles in the Sydney Morning Herald of 30 September headlined `China tries to gag conference', the Canberra Times of 9 October headlined `Chinese police to control students' and the Australian of 21-22 October headlined `Canberra gives in to Beijing bullies'. I ask: Can the Minister confirm that his Department has, since 6 September, been formally made aware by Chinese students and student organisations of no fewer than 10 incidents of harassment by PRC diplomatic representatives of PRC nationals in Australia? Have the allegations been closely reviewed by the Department, as the Minister promised on 6 September? Have the allegations been substantiated and, if so, what action has the Minister taken?

—I cannot vouch for the number of subsequent representations I and my Department have had since 6 September, but I do not contest Senator Hill's suggestion that there may well be that many. I have not had a detailed report yet from my Department as to what it has been able to establish, if anything, from follow-up action. It is an issue that I have been concerned about and have taken up with relevant authorities in Australia, including as recently as last night, seeking further information from them as to what might be known and what might be able to be done about this phenomenon. I will see what I can do by way of giving a further and more detailed answer to Senator Hill, but it may be that there is not much more that I can put on the public record.

—I ask the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs whether a decision has been made with regard to the provision of visas to the Moscow Circus for its provincial tour of Australia. If so, what were the factors taken into account in the Minister's decision in that matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —The Great Moscow Circus has been given conditional approval to make its planned Australian tour in 1990. The Department has decided to grant visas for the tour and I see no reason to interfere with that decision. Country centres have been deprived of international class shows for years and the tour by the Moscow Circus to 23 major country centres I think is a breakthrough. People in country areas will be thrilled to hear that they will see these internationally-renowned performers. The capital cities' loss, in fact, will be the country cities' gain.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department's decision to grant entry to the Moscow Circus followed extensive consultations with the Director of Michael Edgley International, Mr Michael Edgley, the Australian circus owners, the Showman's Guild of Australasia and Actors Equity of Australia. During the consultations Michael Edgley made a commitment to appearances by the Australian Fruit Fly Circus with the Moscow Circus, and he will also sponsor a tour to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics by Circus Oz. Mr Edgley also agreed to share costs with Australian circuses of a research study into the impact of the Moscow Circus on the local circus industry.

The itinerary of the Moscow Circus will be slightly modified as a concession to Australian circus owners. The Moscow Circus tour will create jobs for hundreds of Australians which will more than offset any short-term impact on Australian circuses. I understand-I do not know whether it is still planned-that there might be a demonstration in front of Parliament House by 13 elephants later this week in protest at this decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you got your bucket and spade?

—I hope they do not give birth to another member of the Queensland National Party out there. I hope that will not be the case. There is nothing I can do to stop that particular publicity stunt, and I do not intend to try. I note that the last great elephant invasion by Hannibal was a case where he won all the battles but lost the war. In this case I cannot let an ingenious publicity stunt interfere with what will bring joy to hundreds of thousands of Australians in provincial areas. In the long run I doubt that it will do any damage to the Australian circus industry. I recall that when it was first mooted to bring the ballet from Russia it was thought that it may have an adverse effect on Australian ballet. But it had the exact reverse effect in that it stimulated interest and that particular area has never looked back.

—Does the Minister representing the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industrial Relations agree that, unless one wants to travel only to or between major centres such as Melbourne and Sydney, it remains very difficult to travel by air in Australia without inordinate delays and uncertainty about return arrangements? What does the Government have to lose by instructing its own airline, Australian Airlines Ltd, to talk to the organisation which still obviously represents the vast majority of trained and available pilots in this country? In the interests of the thousands of Australians who want to travel over the Christmas holiday period and the thousands of small businesses facing bankruptcy as this dispute drags on, will the Government at least test the sincerity of the claimed willingness of the Federation of Air Pilots to negotiate on pay, productivity, hours and conditions?

—I do not know what direction the honourable senator would contemplate any government giving to Australian Airlines Ltd commissioners in the circumstances of this dispute. Australian Airlines is a statutory authority run by a board, just as Ansett Airlines of Australia is a private company run by a board.
—It would have a capacity to have both and you know it.

—I do not think that one could say that the circumstances of the two airlines were very different in so far as this industrial dispute is concerned. If we instructed Australian Airlines to do anything, inevitably that instruction would flow on to the other airline and other transport authorities and so on. In relation to the willingness of the pilots to negotiate with the airlines, I only remind Senator Crichton-Browne of the comment made by Mr Justice Brooking in his judgment given in the Supreme Court of Victoria last Thursday, when he said that the pilots set out to create a war and have done it.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In his response is Senator Button saying that this Government lacks capacity to talk to Australian Airlines Ltd to express a view to it as to the direction the Government thinks the disputation should take? Does it lack the capacity to encourage the commissioners of Australian Airlines to talk to the union?

—I think the question is just misconceived. Australian Airlines Ltd is a statutory authority, and I suppose that the Government can talk to its statutory authorities in the same way as it can talk to any other airline. I do not think there is a special position which bears on the pilots dispute.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I cannot let the Minister's favourable comments relating to Mr Justice Brooking go unchallenged. I assume that the Government is opposed to conscription of labour and I assume that the Government supports a worker's right to strike. Having regard to the Prime Minister's statement this morning that that right is not an absolute right, could the Minister tell me what are the principles to which the Government believes regard should be had by industrial organisations and their members in the exercise of this right? If the Government upholds the right to strike, what action, legislative or otherwise, does it intend to take to ensure that that right to strike is upheld? Was it not clear from the beginning that any decision in the Victorian Supreme Court in the pilots case would have the gravest ramifications for all registered industrial organisations, both employer and employee, as well as for all workers in this country and their conditions and wages? This being the case, why did the Government not intervene in this case? Who made that decision not to intervene? Is it not a fact that there is a significant material difference between the current Australian system and the British precedents upon which much of the Brooking decision was based and, indeed, in the relationships between registered industrial organisations in Australia and their members, and British trade unions and their members? Finally, I ask--
—Get on with it. Stop making speeches.

—It is an important question. In view of the likely consequences of the Victorian Supreme Court decision on Australian registered industrial organisations and the industrial systems, both Federal and State, in this country, will the Government say now that it intends to intervene in any appeal against the Victorian Supreme Court decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am always in favour of preparing answers to questions as much as possible. I am also in favour of preparing questions. Senator Harradine has asked a number of questions, some of which are based on totally false assumptions--
—Like what?

—And they have not been given very much thought. The honourable senator began with the false assumption that I quoted with approval what Mr Justice Brooking said on a particular point. He began with that assumption and he went on to make a number of others. For example, he made the assumption that the Commonwealth Government could have intervened in a civil action in the Victorian Supreme Court between the airlines and the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. I doubt that very much and I doubt whether the Commonwealth Government, or any other government, would be given the right to intervene in any appeal against that decision. So there are a number of assumptions which are not quite correct. Further, in relation to whether this Government would take legislative action to protect what the honourable senator terms the right to strike, I answered that question yesterday and I do not need to repeat that answer.

ANSWER.PARA: The right to strike has always been inherent in the common law. However, the right to strike is limited from jurisdiction to jurisdiction and from circumstance to circumstance by the legislative action of various parliaments or various types of industrial relations systems which exist in various common law countries and States of the Commonwealth here. This case involving the air pilots, which Mr Justice Brooking decided last week, is not new in the Australian context. The honourable senator has been sitting in this Senate when other judgments of a similar kind have been made about which he or anybody else has said nothing in particular at that time. So I think the right to strike is there. I do not think it can be a totally unqualified right.

As I said yesterday in answer to a question from Senator Chaney, there are circumstances in which the common law courts will be reluctant to entertain jurisdiction because there is an industrial code of some kind or another covering the field of industrial relations issues. I think that has been so in a number of cases here in Australia. In the air pilots case there was no such industrial code; there was no employment relationship. At the time the proceedings were brought employment had been terminated. So the fact of the matter is that the legislative prescriptions in this country in various State jurisdictions and, to some extent, in the Federal jurisdiction have limited the right of action by employers against employees exercising the right to strike. Undoubtedly, the right to strike exists and has for a long time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I apologise to the Minister if I was rather emotional earlier but I ask him to have a look at precisely the terms of my question. Will he give me an answer to the questions which I asked him and to which he has not responded? My supplementary question is in respect of a comment by the Minister about no industrial relations system applying at the time that the action was taken. Surely he does not mean that the situation in respect of which Mr Justice Brooking made his decision related to that time? Surely it was in respect of a time when the pilots award was in existence and when the pilots were actually employees of the companies?

—I have not read Mr Justice Brooking's decision and nobody else has either but there have been all sorts of commentaries about it. As I understand it, it will be available on Thursday. All sorts of people around the country have been commenting about Mr Justice Brooking's decision and I suspect that none of them has read it. I do not intend to go into the details of that decision until I have read it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, Minister for Industrial Relations and Treasurer. Now that the airlines stand to gain massive damages as a result of their action against the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, will the Government be asking Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines Ltd to pay back at least some of the millions of dollars in taxpayers' funds which have been forgone because of the Government's decision to provide financial support to the industry?

—I do not know what will happen as a result of Mr Justice Brooking's decision. I rather suspect that there will be an appeal, but I do not know. It is certainly too early days to say that the airlines will be seeking to satisfy awards of damages against air pilots. Therefore, it is too early days for the Government to make any comment about the question. If I might say so, even if I were in a position to make a comment, I would say only that the question displays a touch of ingenuity which is wonderful at Question Time but rather silly in any practical circumstances because, of course, it would not affect the Government's decision.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. First, has the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs ascertained how and when former Victorian National Safety Council of Australia Chief, John Friedrich-alias Johann Hohenberger-entered Australia? Secondly, is Friedrich registered as an Australian citizen? If so, on what date was he granted citizenship and how was he able to conceal the fact that he was an illegal entrant? Thirdly, can the Minister explain how an illegal entrant came to be appointed to head the Victorian branch of the National Safety Council of Australia and thereby develop privileged access to possibly sensitive information from a number of Commonwealth government departments and statutory bodies? Fourthly, does the Minister intend to grant Friedrich an entry permit to enable him to remain in Australia after 19 December, at which date he will presumably be subject to mandatory deportation under section 17a of the Migration Legislation Amendment Act 1989?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I hold no brief on the particular judgment, but is Mr Friedrich the subject of actions before the courts at present? Does the question go to any of those matters which are before the courts?
—I did not think that he was. Perhaps the Minister can clear up the situation in his answer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me put it in this way, Mr President: nothing in my answer would go in any way against anything that is held against Mr Friedrich in court, I believe. From my point of view, we have no record of entry to Australia or grant of Australian citizenship to Mr John Friedrich. Mr Friedrich's marriage certificate shows his place of birth as Munich, Germany. Mr Johann Friedrich Hohenberger arrived in Melbourne on 20 January 1975 and was issued with a temporary entry permit until 22 January 1975, when he evidently departed. We have no records of any subsequent re-entry by Mr Hohenberger. The Department believes that Mr John Friedrich and Johann Friedrich Hohenberger are the same person. This view is also supported by the Australian Federal Police. The Department has written to Mr Friedrich's solicitor to establish Mr Friedrich's immigration status. In fact, we have written on two occasions and no reply has been received to date.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the third part of the question, it does not fall within my ministerial responsibility if an organisation outside the Federal Government's jurisdiction appoints someone to a particular position or not. As to the last question, any action by my Department to detain or deport Mr Friedrich at this stage would be inappropriate in view of the potential Victorian Supreme Court proceedings. Any future action on this matter will depend on his immigration status at the outcome of the court proceedings and consideration of other relevant factors.

I make the point that after 19 December mandatory deportation will exist and it will be one of the factors, I hope, that will discourage illegal immigrants from staying in Australia. I know that all sections of the Act were not given full support in this chamber. However, they will become law and it will be much more difficult for illegal entrants to remain in Australia and, once discovered, it will be much easier to return them to where they came from.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. With regard to the Minister's answer to the last part of my question, could he please indicate under what section in the Migration Legislation Amendment Act 1989 the Minister will not have to put a deportation order on Mr Friedrich after 19 December?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —A variety of courses of action would be open to Mr Friedrich. I am not about to give him advice from the Senate chamber. He may apply to stay in this country on the basis of changed circumstances. After all, he has a family in this country. He has two days upon apprehension to make a variety of claims. I also draw Senator Jenkins's attention to, I think it was, a New South Wales Supreme Court ruling of two months ago. If the legal authorities in this country seek to have Mr Friedrich stay here, they may seek an injunction to do so. Admittedly, the legal precedent that I am referring to relates to the old Act and not the new Act. I am not about to give a legal opinion as to exactly where the superior power would lie at this stage.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask whether the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training has seen a letter from Senator Watson which was published in the Hobart Mercury today, in which he says:

QUESTION.PARA: Skillshare will be integrated into the Jobtrain program; only the name will change.
Is the Government contemplating a similar rationalisation of its active work force programs? If so, what would the savings from such a rationalisation achieve?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of any proposed changes which might rationalise active manpower policies which are currently being implemented by the Government. I have had Senator Watson's letter drawn to my attention. He was commenting on Opposition policy. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: Skillshare will be integrated into the Jobtrain program; only the name will change.

I understand that Senator Watson said that because some concern has been expressed in Tasmania about this aspect of the coalition's Economic Action Plan. If I might say so, with a classic piece of Opposition newspeak, Senator Watson has attempted to allay this concern by talking about the integration of Skillshare and Jobtrain with only the name changing, but he has neglected to advise readers of the Mercury of the savings which are inherent in the Opposition's plan. In the attachments to the coalition's Economic Action Plan, the relevant shadow Minister, Mr Beale, says this:

Skillshare, a scheme built on the ruins of the discredited community youth support scheme, will be phased out as soon as possible. Emphasis on finding employment for the long term unemployed and disadvantaged will be concentrated through the Jobtrain program.

Underneath Mr Beale's statement, the document spells out savings of $61m per year out of the program. These are the savings one gets when nothing is changing but the name. According to Senator Watson, only the name is changing. But $61m is to be taken out of those programs of active manpower policies currently being implemented by the present Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Given the now well documented evidence of the devastating effect of record interest rates-from 22 per cent to 25 per cent-for farmers and small business, which not only threaten the viability of those involved but also will kill the investment necessary to increase productivity and exports so essential for the nation's economic future, I ask the Minister: Are there any measures that the Government will undertake before the end of the current year to give some hope to many of the farmers and small business people for Christmas? What action will the Government guarantee to take to reduce this burden being borne by such a vital sector of our economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had questions of this kind addressed to me before, but only recently by Queensland National Party senators. I think the vice that one has to deal with in all issues is what used to be called usury, whether it be in some high interest rates or whether it be in corrupt governments which use the proceeds of the taxpayers for purposes which are not normally associated with government. I think that is the issue which is prevalent in the minds of Queenslanders as they approach the next election. Senator Bjelke-Petersen has asked what the Government will do by Christmas. There certainly will not be a Federal election before Christmas.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Stone said here yesterday that if a Liberal-National Party government were ever elected to this place it would not immediately lower interest rates-and of course it could not do so. So, I think Senator Stone was telling the truth, and that means that even under the best possible scenario for the Liberal Party and the National Party, that is to say, an election in three months' time, and then being elected-a nightmare I suspect for most of the people of Queensland-it would still be a lot longer before anything could be done about interest rates, even by this collection of geniuses that we have on the Opposition benches! I do not think they could do anything in government, let alone reduce interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to stick around to see?

—Too right I am. I will be here. If I might say to Senator Bjelke-Petersen, she has done her duty by the Kingaroy branch of the National Party in asking her question. She can go back and tell it that the Government will not do anything about interest rates until such time as demand in this economy is reduced. This is something that I have said again and again in the Senate. I have not changed my views. The honourable senator might tell her branch that. I hope she will also tell it that even if her lot were elected they would not do anything about it either. If she does not tell it that she will get a pimple on her tongue.

—Has the Minister for Resources seen reports of allegations that the Resource Assessment Commission inquiry into the forestry industry is no more than a delaying tactic by the Government? Are the allegations correct? Is it intended, as the allegations suggest, that the Commission only rehash data which is already available? If not, how will the inquiry be conducted and what faith can we have in the seriousness of its purpose and its integrity once completed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports in several newspapers today which in similar terms quote Senator Chris Puplick, the shadow Minister for the environment, in criticising the Prime Minister's announcement of the terms of reference of the Resource Assessment Commission inquiry into the forestry industry. The first thing I say about this is that the Government's legislation on the Resource Assessment Commission was supported in the end by the Australian Mining Industry Council, the Australian Petroleum Explorers Association, the National Farmers Federation, the National Association of Forest Industries and by conservation groups. It appears that, notwithstanding that support, Senator Puplick has another view.

ANSWER.PARA: On the second point, I might say that the Resource Assessment Commission is headed by a distinguished judge in Australia, Justice Stewart. For this reference he is joined by a former Associate Professor of Economics at Macquarie University, David James, and the Chief Research Scientist with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's Wildlife and Ecology Division, Graham Caughley, to constitute a bench to inquire into forestry in Australia, in all of its dimensions.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bench?

—A bench for the Commission. Commissions in this country have benches if there is more than one person sitting on them. I could go on and enlighten the honourable senator but to do that would take all of Question Time. I do not have the time. The honourable senator's enlightenment will have to wait for a more appropriate opportunity. The information that is currently available for a consideration of a reference of this nature is held by forestry commissions in the various States of Australia but is also held, for example, in the Australian Conservation Foundation's Wood and the Trees document, a study into plantation forestry by that body, and in the Forest and Forest Products Industry Advisory Council (FAFPIC) plan for the future of the industry. Both of those organisations would say, if one were to ask them, that that information is now old and a little out of date and needs updating.

ANSWER.PARA: In any case, this Government has currently on foot with the States a survey to constitute a national forest inventory for Australia and, as we speak, is fashioning a national plantation strategy for Australia, not to mention the fact that forestry information coming out of Tasmania since the historic Labor-Green accord-which has led to the Salamanca agreement between the industry, the Government, the Commission and environmentalists on management of forests in that State-has also produced quite startlingly new evidence and is set to produce further evidence.

In addition, our agreement with the State of New South Wales for a south-east forest agreement covering studies on flora and fauna, flitch mills, small and round wood, value added and saw milling will produce new and better evidence. Therefore, given that this format-the Resource Assessment Commission-is to invite the public and/or community organisations and industry groups to make submissions to it so that there can be a sense of public inquiry, it is proper that it should take the time span allocated to it. The criticisms of it by the Opposition are nothing short of carping, narrow and insensitive, and we expect to come out of this process a sustainable development recommendation. This is the very sort of process recommended in the Brundtland report-the report of the World Commission on Environment and Development-and is the sort of route that this Government announced in its environment program.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Has the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service recently undergone reforms to improve its cost efficiency? Can the Minister advise as to the effectiveness of these reforms? Is he aware of suggestions for improvements to the cost efficiency of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service from any other interested parties? Has the Government had the opportunity to evaluate these suggestions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service underwent a full review, resulting in the Lindsay report. An interim copy of that report was delivered early in 1988 and a full copy later that year. As a consequence, the Government reviewed the operations of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. In doing so, it consulted widely with industry groups, including the National Farmers Federation. The result of that review was a big tick by all the organisations concerned that we had a lean and efficient organisation which would guarantee the very high standard of quality and protection that the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service delivers.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I am aware that the Opposition spokesman for primary industries, Mr Bruce Lloyd, has just issued a media release in which he says a number of things that I had previously cautioned the Opposition not to say. He makes aspersions about the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service in relation to fire blight when he knows full well that a discussion paper is circulating on that subject and that no decision has been taken. He makes aspersions about transmittable gastroenteritis when he knows that nothing has happened yet and that we are in fact in consultation with pig producers around Australia and reviewing their concerns about that issue. He makes aspersions about black spot, when that was an example of successful detection by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and about nashi fruit when he knows that no protocol is yet signed.

We have here a group of misrepresentations about the effectiveness of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. I now again and for the final time caution Mr Lloyd and ask him to stop trying to undermine the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service because, if he were to continue this process, I believe it would do serious damage to Australia's export effort.

On the other hand, the Opposition is proposing direct cuts of $10m in funding under its Economic Action Plan. As a consequence of other changes, the total reduction in funding to the Quarantine and Inspection Service would be something of the order of $26m. Therefore, the Opposition would be gelding the Service quite considerably of the essential funds it needs to deliver the protection to the rural community. If this continual criticism of the Inspection Service continues, the Government will have no option but to raise again the sorry dilemma that arose for rural producers in this country when Australia's reputation as a fair and successful trader was besmirched by the Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd scandal, the meat substitution racket and a number of other events that affected our trading position in the world as a producer of good traded goods on the world market. I conclude by saying that there is something passing odd about Mr Bruce Lloyd's press release of last week relating to meat inspectors, in which he says:
This measure alone would remove 350 or about 2000 meat inspectors, the major employment category and cost to AQIS.

If it removed 350 or about 2,000-there are only about 2,000 meat inspectors employed-according to Mr Bruce Lloyd's own words there would be no meat inspectors to carry out the essential work that is being done in Australia in protecting the public of Australia and ensuring a high standard of quarantine and health protection for overseas clients of our meat output.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday, 21 November, Senator Powell asked me a question about literacy grants. I have an answer for Senator Powell but, as it is somewhat lengthy, I ask that it be incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

The decision to combine the Adult Literacy, Advanced English Program for Migrants and the Non-Governmental Adult Education Program into one program was taken in order to improve targeting and improve access by the most disadvantaged groups to courses providing for their basic vocational education and literacy needs.

Administrative arrangements for the program are to be developed in consultation with a number of relevant advisory bodies including the National Consultative Council on International Literacy Year (NCCILY), the National Office of Overseas Skills Recognition (NOOSR) and the Working Party on Post-Secondary English as a Second Language.
There has been no decision to transfer administration of the new program to the Commonwealth Employment Service.
Beyond the objective of ensuring assistance is directed to disadvantaged groups, there has been no decision concerning specific target groups in the future, including migrants.
States are represented on the ILY Implementation Working Group, which is, in effect a standing committee of the NCCILY.

The Minister for Employment, Education and Training recently approved interim arrangements for 1990, thus allowing sufficient time to give full consideration to issues raised by the NCCILY and community groups.
These arrangements in effect preserve the status quo for the component programs, and will not result in any shifting of program assistance away from the existing target groups.
In taking the decision to combine the programs, the Government in no way intended to imply that individual projects funded under previous programs were not meeting their objectives.
Its intention was to achieve improved efficiency through more precise targeting and greater accountability.
Ensuring the Government's social justice objectives are being met is a significant element in the current consultation on future programs arrangements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 November Senator Bishop asked me how much John Singleton Advertising had received from public moneys since the 1987 Federal election. I am advised that the agency received $53,922 after the Federal election for work done prior to that election on the previous Australia made campaign. Since then he has received $57,628 for his work on the current buy Australian-made campaign and a further $3,000 for his submission.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Friday, 24 November, Senator Vanstone asked me a question without notice about certain questions on form S6, the medical report form which applies to candidates for permanent appointment to the Commonwealth Public Service and for superannuation benefits. Form S6 serves two purposes as it enables the Commonwealth Medical Officer to determine whether candidates are able to meet the requirements of the Public Service Act to serve three years without taking excessive sick leave, and to determine the level of superannuation benefits when an officer retires on the grounds of invalidity.

ANSWER.PARA: Questions on the form are asked in confidence. Nevertheless, all such forms used in the Australian Public Service should use appropriate language and be gender neutral, as far as possible. Normal functions associated with the reproductive cycle should not be identified as a source for categorising a medical condition. In respect of the specific three questions identified by Senator Vanstone I would like to comment that question No. 56 has been reworded since July 1989 to apply generally about breast cancer and that particular wording is not used any more. However, questions 57 and 58 are about menstruation and pregnancy and should be reviewed to ensure that they relate only to a specific long term medical condition. However, because I believe there is an overall need for a review of the wording and the use of the form, I have written to my colleagues the Minister for Finance, the Minister for Industrial Relations and the Minister for Community Services and Health seeking their advice and suggesting that the Australian Women's Health Network should be involved in the review.

DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH INSURANCE (VOCATIONAL REGISTRATION OF GP'S) REGULATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a brief statement regarding a health insurance regulation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 August the Government tabled in the Senate Health Insurance (Vocational Registration of GP's) Regulation, Statutory Rules No. 270 of 1989. This was done as part of the Government's response to the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance which reported on the vocational register of general practitioners. Today is, I think, the last day on which any honourable senator could give notice for disallowance of this regulation. I simply wish to indicate that, after considering this matter, the Opposition has decided not to give such notice. As will be known, we opposed the passage of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act 1989. We have now had a look at the regulation which has been promulgated as a result of the passage of that Act and under section 10 of the Act. Concerns which we raised were in relation to the question of control of certain activities by way of regulation. In terms of the practical operation of the register, however, the crucial issue is not what is now contained in the regulations but rather what is contained in the guidelines published by the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP), which are used to assess the eligibility for admission to the register. Personally, I object to the amalgamation of the roles of the IAC and the Inter-State Commission. I do so on three principal grounds. Firstly, I believe that it would be constitutionally incorrect to incorporate the Inter-State Commission into what is essentially a government-controlled body. The Inter-State Commission was established under the Constitution as an administrative body with `such powers of adjudication and administration as the Parliament deems necessary . . . relating to trade and commerce and of all laws made thereunder'. The only way to assess the constitutional consistency of the amalgamation would be through the High Court of Australia. However, there is unlikely to be a High Court challenge. The Inter-State Commission is to be left with no resources to mount one and, at this stage, there has been no indication that any of the States will intervene on its behalf. We sincerely hope they do.

Secondly, I deplore the manner in which the Government has gone about deciding to amalgamate the Inter-State Commission and the IAC. It made this decision without any consultation with the Inter-State Commission. Thirdly, the role of the ISC is to be an objective arm's length body examining and advising on matters of trade and commerce that require a balance of national and State interests or of competing State interests. It is not in the best interests of this country to have this body under the control of the government of the day and, therefore, subject to its policies.

I commend the Inter-State Commission on its work over the years and particularly during the last financial year. In the short time available, I wish to draw attention to a small number of matters. The paper contains nine very interesting recommendations and eight suggestions. Suggestion No. 2 is crucial and urgent and I hope that the Government will do something about it before the new academic year begins. The suggestion is:

That, as the Schools Council believes that sooner or later four-year training must be a necessary minimum for the great majority of teachers, more data be gathered on its costs and on the scaled implementation related to the supply and demand situation.

I am not concerned about that. Rather, the paper draws attention to a problem which is occurring from the amalgamation of colleges of advanced education (CAEs), which generally have three-year teacher training courses, and universities, which tend to have four-year teacher training courses. When those CAEs are amalgamated, most of the courses will become degree courses. So there will be quite a number of three-year degree courses in teaching and another lot of four-year degree courses.

In terms of the attractiveness for teachers, it is obvious that the three-year courses will win out-a teacher will be able to get into the classroom a year earlier, earn a living a year earlier and receive exactly the same type of recognition in the education community as teachers who have completed a four-year course. If the Government is genuine about wanting a four-year-trained teaching force, as I think there should be in this country, it will have to move very rapidly to do something about this anomaly that has arisen directly as a result of the Government's decisions.
Another suggestion, which is also extremely important, states:
That higher educational institutions continue to explore and research selection processes to improve the likelihood of those admitted to teacher education courses being suitable for teaching.

At the moment there is a dearth of applicants for teaching. This fact was exemplified by the main newspaper in my State, the Courier-Mail, which reported that one of the top people in mathematics graduating from school this year said that he would need to have his head read if he thought of going into teaching. With that type of attitude abroad, where the best in the community see teaching as an also-ran profession, we are on a slippery road to where the United States currently is with teachers being paid about the same as bus and tram conductors and being valued at about the same level. If we want that situation, we are heading in the right direction. Unless the teaching profession is given the right kind of resources and status, we will be proceeding down that very slippery road, no matter what other type of so-called economic moves this or any other government wishes to make.

The only other item I wish to refer to relates to the section of the paper that deals with students with disabilities. It is unfortunate that the paper falls into the identical trap that most people who talk about disabilities fall into. It talks only about what we can do for students with disabilities. In terms of attracting teachers for children who have learning, physical or emotional disabilities, it never mentions the fact that we should be seeking actively to encourage people with disabilities to enter the teaching profession. There is absolutely no mention in the paper that they would be extremely well qualified to teach as they themselves suffer from disabilities and would know what it is like to exist in our community with those disabilities. As with anybody else in our community, a large number of those people would be very well qualified if they were trained. It is a pity that there is no mention of or support given to that aspect in this paper on teacher quality.

This paper is an excellent start. I think it shows that we have in the National Board of Employment, Education and Training a body that is willing to tackle the major issues that are emerging in the profession.

There has been an enormous increase in the number of staff resources available to Ministers in the life of the Hawke Government. There are some notable exceptions, but the list of names of the consultants who have been engaged by the Government in the last 12 months, in 1989-90, reads like a Who's Who of the Labor Party. That is a continuation of the trend that has occurred in recent years.

I and many others on this side of the chamber have continued to draw attention to what we believe is a blatant abuse of this Act of Parliament and a blatant abuse of the taxpayers of Australia. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. I now move away from the specific questions and look, instead, at the report of Estimates Committee D to the Senate. There are a number of items relating to the Department of Defence which concerned the Committee. They are: assistance to the civil community; the Sanderson report; whether the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal is in breach of its statutory obligation under section 58 (h) (6) relating to the review of pay and allowances every two years; and the purchase of 15 light armoured vehicles-the LAV25-in a rather unusual manner, partly in that it was very speedy compared with the norm in the Department.

SPEECH.PARA: I would first like to speak about the Sanderson report. I expressed concern during the hearing in fairly trenchant terms, and my colleagues were fully prepared to support me in my criticism. This study by General Sanderson needed to take place. However, I feel that it was flawed from the beginning in the terms of reference which the general was given. I mean, in particular, that he was not proceeding parallel with an equivalent, concurrent civilian study, which I think is desperately needed in the Department. He was restricted as to what he could look at under his terms of reference. I see we have a copy of the terms of reference now. The general was told to look at a number of things. One was that, in the logistics area, he could look at removing any duplication between service officers and commands, as far as is practicable. That highlights to me the fact that there was any amount of duplication and wasted effort in terms of military and civilian work in a variety of areas in the Department, but he was not given a similar instruction to look at removing any duplication between military and civilian employees.

In clause 6 of his directive he was told that the nature of the structural changes envisaged could affect departmental structures and working arrangements, and he was to consult with relevant areas in the Department and identify areas in which his proposals might impact on civilian staffing arrangements. It was a bit like telling him to go out and do the job with one hand behind his back. What is desperately needed is a total review of the civilian and military interface-to use a word I cannot bear. If the waste through double-guessing that we know goes on in the Department could have been studied, or the two areas of the Department-the civilian and military areas-could have been studied concurrently, we might have had a result of more long term value to the defence of Australia and the morale of the Australian Defence Force.

I draw attention to the fact that Mr McLeod, the Deputy Secretary, Budget and Management, said that the Secretary had done an equivalent civilian review but when he was asked further about the matter he said:

The Secretary's review has not been contained in a single report as such, as was the case with the Sanderson report. It has been the sum of a number of different reviews and exercises of restructuring within the Department that have occurred as part of the normal process of review.
I asked whether there was any reason why the Secretary's review could not be made public as will happen with the Sanderson report. Mr McLeod said:
In some cases there would have been documents which would have given rise to the Secretary considering his options as to the manner in which the top structure of the Department should be reorganised.
He finished by saying:
The results of that review process are not necessarily fully reflected in a documentary form.

He never really came to grips with why there could not be any public study of what had been happening in these so-called reviews of the civilian side. I, for one, have my doubts about how much civilian review there has been. It seems to me that every time I try to ask questions about redundancies or rationalisation on the civilian side of the Department there is simply a shuffling of figures which draws rather heavily on the fact that a number of people have been moved out of the former Office of Defence Production into Aerospace Technologies of Australia Pty Ltd and Australian Defence Industries and that is really not what I am on about at all. I am looking to see how that Department can be fined down to be an effective and efficient body.

Turning again to General Sanderson's report, its implementation is taking place and is expected to be finalised by February next year. The Committee found, and said so in its report, that factors of its implementation were quite discriminatory; there was quite inappropriate treatment of military officers compared with civilian officers who have been made redundant and no attempt was being made to treat service positions with the same redeployment opportunities which are offered to senior public servants. I and my colleagues believe that it should be within the competence of the Department of Defence to actively seek redeployment for displaced officers.

Another matter relating to the Sanderson report which I find particularly offensive is that, even to this date, I understand that officers who have been fingered for redundancy have not been told specifically what their redundancy packages will be. They have no choice in the matter. They are being compulsorily made redundant. They have a gun at their heads but they do not yet know what their financial package will be. They do not know what they will get or when they will get it. How can anyone in that position make plans or work out finances? It is one of the most badly managed manpower cases I have ever come across. It is disgraceful in the extreme that there has been no public protest from the Defence Force leadership. It is also despicable that two Ministers for Defence have allowed this to happen.

Of course, we are all very well aware of the terrible wastage rates from the defence forces, which are continuing. One of the reasons for the wastage spelled out in the report by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, which reported last November, a year ago, was that the defence forces felt that they had little or no support from either their political or military leaders. The way in which the Sanderson report is being implemented is a classic case of lack of support. Just before I finish talking about the lack of support that we give to our servicemen, I draw attention to a plight facing some servicemen, although not a great number. It is a case of lack of understanding of the special requirements put on people who are asked to move from place to place for the sake of their country. This Government has failed them in the ways that really show that their service is important and that therefore as people and as human beings they deserve protection. I am talking about a case-there are increasing numbers of such cases-where a father has gone through the divorce courts and has the custody of his children. Such a man is not entitled to a married quarter in the Australian Defence Force, even if he has his mother to keep house for him.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is ridiculous.
—It is absolutely ridiculous. He is also not entitled to removal expenses.
—It is wrong in the first place.

—The Minister may say that I was wrong, but I have had representations from people who are in exactly that position. If the Minister can tell me that that is not the case and demonstrate how, I will be very glad. The way the system is being administered now, that is what is happening to people. Surely a man who does not have a dependent spouse but who has dependent children living with him should be entitled to a married quarter and, therefore, removal expenses. After all, such a man would need that married quarter and removal expenses because he does not live where he chooses to live but where the Defence Force requires him to live and he has to move where the Defence Force requires him to move. Does the Minister want to respond to that now?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose it is best to take the last point first. Senator Newman is simply not correct. It has always been the case-I suppose `always' is a big word, but it has been the case for a long time-that the test is one of dependency, not marriage. Senator Newman referred to fathers. If a service father can demonstrate that he has dependent children, he is eligible for married quarters; there is no question about that. I invite Senator Newman to ask the person whom she alleges has complained to her to contact either me or the Department because her information is simply not right. There must be some other element in play of which we are not aware.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not quite certain what to say about the general thrust of Senator Newman's remarks concerning lack of support for service personnel, except that, if they are looking for support, they will not go to Senator Newman. Redundancy issues are never easy. When people are made redundant, inevitably there will be a certain amount of discomfort and pain. That cannot be avoided. But from the outset we have sought to minimise that discomfort and we will continue to do so. The redundancy package for the people in question has been agreed to. All those affected are aware of what is in the package and we expect final Department of Industrial Relations approval in a very short period.

To go back further to those things that led up to this, it is sufficient to say that the Sanderson review certainly looked at the issue of logistics, including in the Department. Since the end of October we now have a new organisation in place which incorporates the Secretary's review of logistics and its recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recognise that the entitlement to married quarters does not depend upon a person having a married spouse. It depends upon a person having a dependent spouse and children. Consequently, if a man has his mother looking after his dependent children, he is not entitled to a married quarter. I stand by that claim.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
