TALK.START.PARA: —I can only go on what my advisers are telling me and they are quite adamant that, following divorce, if custody has been awarded to a father and the children are dependent upon that father, he is entitled to married quarters.
—But there were advisers who were nodding in what appeared to be agreement with what I was saying just now.
—The advisers stand by what I have just said. I appear to have the numbers unanimously over here.

—Perhaps I had better go back to writing about this because certainly people have been refused on exactly the grounds that I have raised. If they are eligible for these things, I will be very glad to ensure that they get their entitlements. If they are not eligible, we had better do something about it. The Minister also referred to the redundancy package. I ask him more specifically whether those people know in detail what they will be entitled to, or whether they know only in general terms-48 weeks, et cetera-which they have known for perhaps a couple of months?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as I am aware, they know all of the details of the redundancy package. They are also aware that it requires final Department of Industrial Relations approval, although I do not expect that there will be any difficulty in that being obtained. I am not aware of anything that has been hidden from them; they are aware of the full contents of the package.

—I just want to know whether they know more than they knew a couple of weeks ago. I see that Admiral Beaumont is nodding agreement that they do know more than they did then. At that stage they knew it was still subject to approval, which made them all feel very uncertain. Even if the Minister does not think that that is uncertain, they do. They did not know the financial details; they only knew the principles on which the package would be based, which was leading to very great unhappiness in the people to whom I have spoken. The Minister has said that the time of redundancy is never very happy; but at least it is a lot better if redundancy is an option or if one is given help in finding alternative employment. These people have not had any assistance with redeployment, according to the questions we asked and the answers we got during the Estimates committee hearings. They are being treated completely differently from those in the Senior Executive Service in the Public Service in that the Defence Force personnel have no choice in the matter; they are being made compulsorily redundant. In those circumstances one would expect the financial package to be more generous than the standard package offered to people who choose redundancy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —As part of the redundancy exercise, naturally enough, assistance is available to people in that position. The Department has arranged for re-employment assistance which can take the form of counselling and further direct assistance if necessary. That assistance would be directed towards Public Service employment if so desired by the candidate. Obviously Public Service employment is determined by another Act with its own requirements. There can be some difficulties, given that merit is now an accepted principle.
—What?
—The merit system means that there cannot be favouritism in employment-I only refer to it in that sense-and that can add a difficulty.

—Can the Minister explain that? It sounded as though he was reflecting on the merit of the people in the defence forces. I understand that there are priorities for admission of people into the Public Service who have English as a second language, or Aboriginals. There are quite a few criteria for priority. Is the Minister saying that people he is compulsorily making redundant in the Defence Force could not be given some such priority of redeployment? Would he also answer exactly what he meant when he vaguely mentioned that people are being redeployed in the Public Service? Does he mean that he is putting in place a program to assist people to be redeployed? Clearly he is not going to give them any priority. What exactly did the Minister really mean?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Having to explain the obvious is sometimes necessary where Senator Newman is concerned. She did not mention that under the Public Service Act there is now a prohibition on favouritism, discrimination, patronage, et cetera. To ignore that is to sweep aside a possible problem. It does not rule these people out; I never said that it did. I merely mention it as one aspect. I have stated that counselling is available for people in this situation for re-employment assistance. At the Estimates Committee D hearing-indeed, in the report-there were questions that related to redeploy of officers in this position to the Australian Public Service. That is why I raised the question. It is in the report and I am attempting to answer the queries that have been raised there. All I have said is that the assistance made available to officers who are becoming redundant can be made available to them in seeking to switch to the Australian Public Service if that is their wish.

—Am I to understand from the Minister's response that he equates counselling with practical assistance? Is that the only assistance with redeployment that the Minister means? Is there anything else, because I do not equate that?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Newman may not regard counselling as important in this respect. It is quite clearly apparent now, though, that many of the redundant officers do.
—That is the only thing you are offering.
—No, it is not the only one.
—What else are you offering?

—I said that there was initial counselling and further direct assistance if necessary. All I am saying now to Senator Newman is that officers have expressed their view that counselling is important. In response to that the Department is making sure that it is available.
—Could the Minister please tell me what further direct assistance, if necessary, is being provided, or will be provided?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department will be prepared to supply re-employment assistance in cases where that is considered appropriate. There is also outplacement counselling. We are looking at selecting a firm to assist in this matter and expect to be able to announce the engagement of that firm within the next month.
—This is like drawing teeth. Could the Minister please tell me what `re-employment assistance' actually means?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —It means that we are going to try to find the officers a job. It means that we will go out and seek to identify jobs that they could go for and try to help them get them.
—Have you told them that yet?
—Yes.
—When?
—Approximately a month ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very grateful to hear that. The message has not got through yet. It might be passed by bush telegraph.
—Not to you; it has got through to me.
—I have a good deal more contact with the people concerned than the Minister has, and that is certain.
—That is not becoming obvious from this little exchange.
—I shall send the officers the Hansard with delight, and let them be the judges.
—I hope you do.
—Yes; they got the last lot.
—Good.
—It did not do the Department or the Minister much good either.
—Let us get on with the matter.

—I will move on to another item that has been commented on in the report; that is, the purchase of the LAV 25 armoured fighting vehicles. In this case $25m was allocated for the initial purchase of 15 LAV 25 wheeled armoured fighting vehicles from the United States Marine Corps, including spare parts. The cost of the initial purchase was about $25m. The Committee was not informed of the processes undertaken to access the priority of this need relative to requirements for other equipment and stores. The Committee reported that it considers that the purchase of the vehicles would be an appropriate matter for review by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts or another parliamentary committee.

SPEECH.PARA: This purchase was not mentioned in the Additional Estimates in April. We were told that the resources came from the existing appropriation for equipment and stores, but we were not informed of the process undertaken to get the priority, as I have just said. No arrangements were made to ascertain any Australian industry participation in any additional purchase, and yet we have been told by the Minister that we will need 100. This has added $25m to our balance of payments problem. The vehicles have not been trialled in Australian conditions; they were not evaluated against possible competitors; there are no reports that assess whether a wheeled or a track vehicle was more suitable for our climatic conditions and terrain in the north of Australia where the 2 Cavalry Regiment will be relocated, and these vehicles are for 2 Cavalry Regiment. The Committee had been told last year that one of these vehicles was to come to Australia with the Americans for trials during Kangaroo 89. That did not happen. The first thing we knew was that the Government had bought 15 of them. Major-General Francis, Assistant Chief of Materiel for the Army, confirmed this at the Estimates Committee hearings. He stated:
There was no comparative physical trial or competing vehicles: that is correct . . . we did move very quickly, and we short-circuited the system when the opportunity arose.
It would not be true to say that we have any recommendations that put the LAV above the other contenders. It is our assessment that this vehicle is probably the best . . .

That is hardly the way I would have imagined the taxpayers of Australia would expect defence procurement to operate. Certainly it usually operates on the same basis as anybody with hardening of the arteries-with great difficulty. It is so out of character for any purchases of any magnitude-even small ones for that matter-in the Defence Department to proceed at that pace. One really does wonder how this was allowed to go ahead. I have my suspicions.

Mr Ives, First Assistant Secretary, Resources and Financial Programs Division, suggested that the $25m had to be spent before 30 June, if I recall. I could think of plenty more deserving things that $25m could have been spent on-personnel for one. If it has to come from the same vote, then I regard other areas as more needy. I would have thought that the Defence Department might have moved, first of all, to improve our defence capability and, secondly, to improve our morale. If the Minister has a look at Puckapunyal, for example, he will see that we are short of spare parts for the existing tanks and the armoured personnel carriers. The Armoured Regiment at Puckapunyal at the moment has four tanks without engines at all. God knows what it will do in an emergency. These tanks have been cannibalised for their parts to keep the others running. There is a long time delay in getting spare parts throughout the Defence Force but particularly with the Armoured Corps. This is having an enormous effect on morale. The purchase of the LAVs before dealing with these essentials only exacerbates the problem.

When I asked Major-General Francis whose idea it was to purchase these vehicles, I was told it was collectively that of the Army, the Defence Force and the Department in conjunction with the Minister. Of course it had to go to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to get his approval. I then asked whether it was the Minister's idea and Major-General Francis said, `I think the Minister's interest in this project is well known'.That says it all. That is our Rambo at it again. I believe that the all-party committee--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Newman, that is definitely a breach of standing order 418. I think you should withdraw that remark.

—I withdraw it, Mr Temporary Chairman. Nevertheless, I think very strongly that the all-party committee is totally right, that it would be appropriate for the whole matter to be reviewed by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: I would now like to raise what is perhaps a much smaller matter: flying suits. There is a shortage of flying suits. There has been for several years. I was told at the Estimates Committee hearings that the problem was that we wanted a two-piece flying suit as opposed to the one-piece suit used by the Americans. I was not told why we needed a two-piece suit. No definite answer was given, just a vague indication that it was the preference of the aviators. I have a copy of the Army supply bulletin which has the Nomex flying suits shown on the sensitive list. The list as at August 1989, headed `Sensitive Items', states:
Procurement of Nomex flying suits has been delayed since 1983 due to the unsuitability of the US one piece coverall and the new RAAF 2-piece suit. Depot stocks have been exhausted.
It goes on in some detail about the matter:
Delivery is near completion. Units are not to demand for the new item as issues will be made in accordance with priorities laid down by Army Office.
An EDD of early 1990 has been confirmed for these suits.

I find it quite extraordinary that the provision of flying suits has been delayed since 1983. I am further amazed that although the specifications for the two-piece flying suit were ready in 1987-two years ago-they still will not be ready until early 1990, given the urgency of an item that has been sensitive for six years.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the light of Senator Newman's comments, I think it is necessary to look at the purchase of the light armoured vehicles (LAV). I will just give a little background to that matter. Fourteen LAV-25s and one LAVR wheeled armoured fighting vehicle have been acquired for delivery by mid-1990. The requirement for the wheeled armoured fighting vehicles was not recently identified, but it was identified in 1987 as a priority in the Government's White Paper, which looked at a requirement for rapid and effective ground force operations across northern Australia. It is not difficult to understand why high priority was given to the acquisition of wheeled armoured fighting vehicles in time for the 2 Cavalry Regiment's planned move to Darwin in 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: The LAV-25 has been under consideration for two years or more as part of the development of the wheeled armoured fighting vehicle proposal. The Chief of the Defence Force advised that the purchase of the LAVs was necessary to evaluate operational concepts for the wheeled armoured fighting vehicles in northern Australia. As I think Senator Newman mentioned, about 100 vehicles may eventually be acquired, depending on funding priorities. I could not give an absolute time for that acquisition. The procurement was made under United States foreign military sales regulations, which enable the vehicles to be acquired very quickly. The then Acting Prime Minister, Mr Lionel Bowen, and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) agreed with that approach. A logistics and training package is included in the intitial cost of about $25m, which compares very favourably with vehicles of similar capability. By procuring vehicles from the LAV family, Australia has been able to take advantage of the Marine Corps' extensive comparative evaluation of armoured vehicles, including trials in a wide range of climatic conditions and terrains.

The LAV was one of a limited number of vehicles that could provide the capability sought by the Army. In addition to the advantage of its immediate availability, life support costs for the vehicle are expected to be significantly less than those for comparable vehicles due to our access to US logistic support systems. When it is appropriate-and I think what I have just said lends weight to the argument that it was-defence equipment acquisition can take place with some flexibility in procurement procedures. This was an opportunity that was too good to miss and we did not miss it. That is why it was not included in the 1988-89 Additional Estimates. Due to the size of this initial procurement, the potential for Australian industry participation was limited. Obviously, it will not be ignored and it will certainly be an important factor when the main component of the need for wheeled armoured fighting vehicles is considered.

Senator Newman referred at one point to some tanks which have been cannibalised for spares. We are awaiting tank spares from Germany as part of a normal order. I am advised that there is no evidence of operational shortfalls due to spares shortages for tanks in any event. In the current strategic circumstances, tanks are not of the highest priority.

I will now go to the question of flying suits. Army pilots and crew obviously spend quite a lot of time not dressed in flying suits; they do not fly 24 hours a day. During those periods on the ground, like the rest of us they want to be comfortable and they need a uniform that is versatile and suited to ground operations. A two-piece flying suit is cooler and more comfortable in that it allows for better air circulation around the body. It is less restrictive than a one-piece suit. Additionally, it may be worn with the shirt tucked in or left out. The two-piece suit also offers extra fire protection on the waist-thigh area when the shirt is worn inside the trousers and gives a greater range of movement for the upper body than does a one-piece suit. The one-piece suit needs to be fitted more precisely than the two-piece suit-I am sure it does-with the resultant need to provide a greater size range than for the two-piece suit. The two-piece suit is cheaper to maintain because the whole uniform need not be discarded if only one part is worn or damaged. For all these reasons the Army prefers to use a two-piece suit. I understand that a prototype has been produced. I am not certain of the stage that that is up to. I seek Senator Newman's indulgence in allowing me some time to find out.

When we compare how quickly that Department could spend $25m on some light armoured vehicles and how slowly it has put in place measures which could be saving it many millions of dollars if fraud is taking place in that Department to any level, it is a bit of an irony that one could be so quick and one could be so slow.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his answer. SPEECH.PARA: The report of Estimates Committee D also referred to assistance to the civil community. That was referred to in the majority report and it was also referred to in a reservation by my colleagues Senators MacGibbon and Reid and me. We have very serious concerns about assistance to the civil community. We followed this matter in some detail during the Estimates Committee hearings and we were not satisfied by the answers we got. I have a copy of a document entitled Defence Instructions (General) DI(G) 01-2-which was issued pursuant to section 9a of the Defence Act 1903 and sets down the policy and procedures for aid to the civil community. We asked a lot of questions about that document and it was made clear to us that the document really had a persuasive influence on the Department and the defence forces and it gave them a guide. I could get out the Hansard now, if I chose to, and go through all the words that were used to suggest to us that it was an indication of how the defence forces should operate. At no time was there any suggestion that Defence Instructions (General), were referred to and allowed for in the Defence Act and that the Department was bound to operate according to the procedures laid down.

Some of the officers who were answering our questions described those defence instructions as merely self-imposed disciplines or general policy statements. Specific questions as to whether the DI(G) applied to the provision of the aircraft for the civilian air lift known as Operation Immune were simply avoided in the officers' answers. In the Estimates Committee hearing officers revealed in answers to us that Defence had provided the aircraft following a decision of Cabinet and through instructions subsequently issued by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). It does not appear that the Minister gave any instruction which would have overruled the procedures laid down in the DI(G). From the evidence which we received at the Estimates Committee, it appears that the Defence Instructions (General) were simply ignored because the Minister had said there was a Cabinet decision to use Royal Australian Air Force aircraft.

That is one thing. However, I have here a copy of a document which makes it very clear that the Defence Instructions (General) have the force of law and that it is mandatory for the Department to follow them. I fail to understand why the Department did not treat its own Defence Instructions (General) as having the force of law when it was well aware that it had an opinion from the Attorney-General's Department which said that it was obliged to implement its own Defence Instructions (General). Perhaps the Minister could explain to this chamber why it was not given that authority in this case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Any suggestion that officers of the Department of Defence, or anyone from the forces, attempted to mislead the Committee is something that I must strongly resist. I think it would have been reasonable for those officials to assume that Committee members would be aware that the Defence Act is the only authority for the issue of Defence Instructions (General). They would not have felt the need to point that out. They would have assumed that degree of knowledge. So, I do not find that any sort of problem. Then we get to the nature of the instructions themselves. The instructions are written for the internal administration of Defence Force procedures. They are not, and never have been, all embracing, and no-one has ever suggested that they were.

SPEECH.PARA: The Defence Act makes it clear that the Government, through the Minister, can assign tasks to the forces as seen fit. If and when the Minister or the Government decides to issue an instruction to the forces and it contravenes Defence general instructions, so be it. That is quite properly within the Act and quite properly within the power of the Government and the Minister. In these circumstances the Department would go to the Minister and say, `This is the way we would normally conduct ourselves in this situation'. Obviously, it is then up to the Government to decide whether that is adequate in the circumstances that are prevailing at the time. On this occasion, one would have to say that the circumstances prevailing were not only different from normal but extraordinary, to say the least. The Government, therefore, needed to take action and instructed the forces accordingly.

His Department has leaked letters.
—You cannot assert that.

—The Minister's Department has leaked letters to the media damning a draft environmental impact statement which I have not seen. I do not know who has seen it; maybe one has to be on the special departmental leak list to get it. However, these letters have been leaked, aimed at damaging Minister Beazley's plans, firstly, to move the ammunition depot and, secondly, to see whether or not it is reasonable to move the Navy as a whole to Jervis Bay. They are the matters that are germane to the question I was asking. The Minister says that he does not propose to take action on the leaking of those letters. I ask him whether he regards as normal and acceptable that interdepartmental correspondence should be leaked to the media. Do we take the Minister's initial response that he does not propose to take any action to be some tacit acknowledgment that it is acceptable behaviour for his Department to seek to subvert the activities of other departments by leaking correspondence which is hostile to their objectives?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is absolutely no evidence that my Department did what Senator Baume claims-absolutely none. So, I do not have to deny anything, not a thing. Furthermore, Senator Michael Baume did not listen; so I will tell him again: I point out that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr David Simmons) is the Minister handling this, not the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). However, just for the record, Mr Beazley has been a friend of mine for just as long-and I am not at war with him, either. Clearly, as this process has gone on and on-and I might say that the environmental impact statement has taken a long time to get here-problems with the EIS have become apparent. The Prime Minister has mentioned this, and so have I, in public before. There is no great news about this. It is very old hat.

SPEECH.PARA: I say again that these leaks cannot be attributed to my Department without some evidence. Mind you, when it comes to the use of the smear, Senator Baume's record suggests that evidence is the last thing he ever cares about. Having said that, there are God knows how many people who have seen these letters, in the Department of Defence and in the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories-not to mention people in the company that was doing the EIS in the first place. So, yes, there have been some problems with it, and I have referred to them. In no way does that mean that the Government has decided that it will not do it, but it does put on notice the Department of Defence and in particular those who are preparing the EIS that a great deal of care must be taken.

I think that is now generally acknowledged, and it should be acknowledged even by Senator Baume that Mr Simmons who has carriage of this matter in his portfolio did agree to my providing those letters. So, there has been no shock or horror about this; it has been a quite normal procedure. These letters form part of the normal process; that is, commenting on a draft before it is made public. The thing will be made public anyway in the space of the next few weeks. The letters that have been leaked are `FOI-able', and would have been in the public arena at some point, anyway.

One wonders why there is such a huge outcry. Of course, it is only from Senator Baume. The community at large does not think that this is the hottest issue in town, and never will. In the remarks that I made last week at the launch of Professor Buckley's landmark study of environmental impact statements I stressed-because this is stressed by his work and the findings that he has published-that the best environmental impact statements and the ones that most effectively predict environmental consequences are those that result from processes which have involved public participation to a maximum extent. Over the next few months we will have a draft ready for public comment and for three months everyone will have a chance to look at the EIS and give their comments. That will be an important phase in this operation and it is one that I eagerly await.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for effectively confirming that the leaking of documents from his Department when there has been disagreement with another department is par for the course. Apparently it is considered that it is not the hottest game in town, it does not really matter, it is inconsequential, everyone can see it on television, so why bother about it, anyway. I note the Minister's response to the question of ministerial responsibility in his Department, and it does not surprise me; it is in keeping with his normal standards of behaviour.

SPEECH.PARA: I now ask whether the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has any views on the Royal Australian Navy's case for removing the armaments depot from Newington. There was an impression in last night's Four Corners program that a view was held that there is no sound case for moving the ammunition depot, the armaments complex, from its present location in Sydney's western suburbs. No doubt the Minister is aware of the fact that the armaments depot at Newington involves a chain which does not meet North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) safety requirements. Some people say that that is not relevant.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true. It does meet NATO requirements.

—We have an interjection that it does meet NATO requirements. I must say that I am much more inclined to take the advice that I have received that it does not. The present problem that we have with that armaments depot, as I understand it, is that its location on the Parramatta River, where it has been since 1881, poses real logistical and safety problems. There is another defence armaments depot at Kingswood, which is near Penrith. At present armaments are transported by road through Sydney between Kingswood and Newington and from Newington by barge via the Parramatta River to fleet units in Sydney Harbour.

SPEECH.PARA: If the proposed move of the armaments depot to the north-western part of Jervis Bay-and that is nowhere near the other proposed developments-went ahead, Newington would close and armaments would no longer travel between Kingswood, Newington and Sydney Harbour. The Navy has taken the view that, as Sydney has developed, it has become more difficult to meet appropriate safety standards for the storing and handling of armaments. The present system is also manpower intensive, time consuming and costly. Both the Federal and New South Wales governments are agreed that the Navy's ammunitioning process should be moved. Jervis Bay is the preferred new location.

We thus have a situation in which both governments have agreed that this ammunitioning process should be moved somewhere, with Jervis Bay being the preferred location. It is alleged that, because this ammunition is moved defused, it is therefore not a danger. Anyone who has seen ammunition depots attacked and the evidence of explosions in them would know that, when defused, there is still the prospect of explosions, given the right unfortunate circumstances. In any event, there is no doubt-and it is unarguable-that the burden of opinion, State and Federal, is that this depot should be moved.

Jervis Bay is a beautiful area, and I have spent at least one week every year holidaying there, particularly in the wilderness section. Therefore, I was intrigued by the footage chosen last night-and it was beautiful footage of Jervis Bay-for screening on the Four Corners program. I draw to the Senate's attention the fact that there are thousands of houses around Jervis Bay. The suburb of Vincentia is probably the fastest growing single community on the south coast of New South Wales, and it is located on the shores of Jervis Bay. Huskisson is a well known fishing holiday resort. Callala Beach, Callala Point, Callala Bay and Hyams Beach are all very well developed permanent and temporary holiday areas with a very large permanent population.

It just struck me as incredible that the integrity of the Australian Broadcasting Commission (ABC) is such that it was able to show not one house when photographing Jervis Bay. The impression it gave was that, in its entirety, it was as pristine as the beautiful sections of wilderness that exist in the area surrounding the present naval training station, HMAS Creswell, and certainly those areas where, if the fleet as a whole moved down, two kilometres of the total 65 kilometres of shore would be taken up.

I will not argue the merits or otherwise of the fleet moving there, because I do not have the vaguest idea about that. The proposed armaments depot is to the north-east on a degraded, burnt-out area of forest, and what I have seen of that makes it clearly a sensible, rational and useful choice as an area on which to place an armaments depot-certainly a far better place than the western suburbs of Sydney, where the depot is surrounded by millions of people as the armaments are brought to be loaded onto ships.

As the Navy has pointed out, an armaments complex well inland from the north-western side of Callala Beach and in State, not Commonwealth, territory would affect a degraded pine plantation inland from the bay. However, a jetty on the bay would be needed. With good planning, such a jetty would not affect the bay greatly or be very noticeable. It is possible that no dredging or breakwater construction will be necessary, and disturbance to sea grass and marine life can be avoided.

Of course, we heard none of that in last night's Four Corners program-not a skerrick of the Navy's position was mentioned. The ABC can be one-sided and dishonest if it wants to be. It can show not a house in the whole of Jervis Bay if it wants to, but I wonder what its point is. I wonder to what extent the ABC has been a convenient weapon of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) in this matter, deliberately setting out to damage the Navy's position. The Navy believes that the safety buffer zones required around the armaments complex will ensure that the environment is not disturbed and will actually help to protect native plants and animals. The depot site is remote from residential areas, public utilities and major road systems.

The reason I suggested that perhaps it suited the Minister's book that the ABC took the course that it did on Four Corners is that that approach is in line with the continued attack of the Minister's Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories on the proposal. Whether or not the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Simmons) still has the carriage of it at present, the attack has continued-and this was the public arena element-on the proposal, even the armament area proposal. As I understand it, initially the Navy wanted there to be two entirely distinct and discrete environmental impact statements, one related to the movement of the fleet and the other specifically related to the ammunition proposal. That was admitted before Senate Estimates Committee D. I can tell the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories that and save him the trouble of checking whether I am right; of course I am right. The Navy admitted that it should not have agreed to making it one lumpy 1,600-page-or whatever it is-environmental impact statement, but should have had separate statements.

I am wondering whether the Minister and his Department, as part of their campaign against this overall proposal, maintain a position against simply the ammunition proposal. As I have said, it would bring major benefits to the people of Sydney and would remove the chain of carriage of high explosive ammunition from the far west of Sydney through highly populated areas of Sydney, even though the ammunition is in a defused state. Does the Department lump this proposal in with its disdain for the rest of the Navy's proposal to move to Jervis Bay?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether the producers or journalists on the Four Corners program or I would be more insulted by the honourable senator's allegation that they were in some way a tool of mine. I think Andrew Olle would be having a coronary at this moment if he heard the allegation. I have already said that I did not speak to anyone connected with Four Corners about the program. There was no reason why I should have done so, and I did not.

SPEECH.PARA: I will cover some of the points Senator Michael Baume has raised. He referred several times to the continued attack on the proposal by the Department and by me. There has not been any attack. My Department is exercising its responsibility to ensure the integrity of the environmental impact process. It does that by going to the consultant who has prepared the report on behalf of the proponent-in this case the Department of Defence-and saying, `This draft is inadequate in these ways. You will need to do more work on these sections'. Last night, one of the matters referred to by the Four Corners program was the question of the armaments depot. What my Department quite correctly said was that more work had to be done to justify the need for the move. There is nothing wrong with that. That is the Department fulfilling its statutory requirement. That is the Department doing its job. That is what it is there for. It performs that task on every single EIS, and that it would do so on this one is a matter about which I can only say I am happy.

Regarding this ammunition wharf, I will not say that I agree with everything that Four Corners might or might not have said. I do not know what the program did say, because I did not see it. I was in this chamber answering questions from Senator Boswell and others when it was on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very important questions, too.

—Yes, but I was in here; I was not out watching television, so I do not know what may or may not have been said. It has been suggested to me, and Senator Michael Baume has repeated it, that there was a suggestion in the program that large scale dredging might be necessary for the preferred option of a jetty into Jervis Bay and that breakwaters might need to be constructed. There is no question that the Royal Australian Navy has made it clear that that is not the case, and I acknowledge that. However, I did not ask Four Corners to say the opposite. If the program did, I hope it pays more attention to the cause of accuracy. Whether I make a recommendation for or against it, certainly one has to acknowledge the good work that has been done, and make sure that any inadequacies in that work are remedied.

SPEECH.PARA: It should also be noted that under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act proponents have to look at alternatives. The extent to which they do so can be debated, but feasible alternatives must be examined and it is the job of my Department to ensure that that is done. The idea of combining the two environmental impact statements was decided a long time ago-I think before I was the Minister. I do not believe I was responsible for it but, having said that, I do not regard it as an issue. No-one from Defence has at any time raised it with me and I do not think it is a source of continuing discussion between departments. Whether there are two environmental impact statements on the fleet base and the armaments depot or just the one makes precious little difference. It is a big issue, one that will not go away, and it needs public scrutiny.

If there is an argument to say that even defused ammunition should not be transported between these houses in Sydney, there is probably an argument from some residents around Jervis Bay to say they do not want it transported through there either. As to whether a jetty into the bay is an environmental problem, I suppose beauty, or the lack of it, is in the eye of the beholder. For all those who assert it does no environmental damage, I am sure there will be those who will assert that it will. The important thing is that I, and my Department, have not got a position on this. We will simply wait to see the final draft, what public comment does to that draft and what final document comes from that. At that point I will make a recommendation. I might say that that is all I do. I do not make the decisions around here; I just make recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who makes the decisions?

—Normally speaking, it is the Minister. Mr Temporary Chairman, I hope you will allow me the indulgence of answering that interjection, because it is reasonable. Normally it would be the responsibility of the Minister to make those decisions, and that is mostly what happens. On very big decisions the normal form is for the Minister to bring the matter to Cabinet. I imagine that a proposal such as this would be the subject of a Cabinet decision at the end of the day, but that would be up to the Minister to decide, and I have never asked that question.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I say that neither I nor my Department has a position. The only position we have at the moment is to observe our statutory duty to ensure that there is an environmental impact statement adequate to cope with the very serious environmental questions that are raised by either an armaments depot or a fleet base move to Jervis Bay, and adequate to ensure that all those who have a vital interest in this question can pick up a document and, at least, see the pros and cons of their argument traversed in that document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know where Senator Michael Baume's argument was leading or what he was defending. I do not know whether his concern is for the safety of the people of Sydney or whether he wants to see that the Royal Australian Navy gets its way, but he made some statements which are false. The Newington depot conforms fully with the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) requirements. If there is any difficulty, it is with the wharf and the man-o'-war anchorage which requires a public risk waiver to be issued. The Newington depot itself fully complies with NATO requirements. As Senator Richardson rightly points out, maybe it would cause the people of Sydney to be slightly less afraid of weapons if they did not come from Kingswood and go to Newington, but what about all the people along the several hundred kilometres from Kingswood to Jervis Bay? They would be put at risk on a very high risk road which, in fact, is the location of a number of accidents and these weapons would be subject to explosion if involved in an accident on the road.

SPEECH.PARA: The ammunition issue should be broader than simply whether the depot should be at Newington or Jervis Bay. The Navy itself has recognised the desirability of having ammunition stored further north along the coast. The port of Gladstone has offered itself both as a fleet base and as an ammunition depot, and this would be a likely alternative. The site need not be just either Jervis Bay or Newington. Perhaps the Navy should look at its operation in terms of neither, and move the ammunition depot further afield and avoid all these problems.

The ammunition depot in Jervis Bay would be in two parts, which I did not feel was adequately spelt out. One of the parts will be in degraded forest, and the wharf could be located adjacent to a very fine rain forest area on the coast, and would degrade that. The whole area on that side of Beecroft Peninsula is of great Aboriginal significance, which is a further reason why the ammunition complex should not be put there. I did not quite follow the argument presented by Senator Michael Baume that somehow, as there was settlement at Vincentia and Huskisson, one is supposed to derive from that that it is okay for the ammunition depot or the Navy to go there. He seemed to be very upset that Four Corners did not show the settlements around Jervis Bay, but why should it? At issue were the naval developments which would change the whole aspect of Jervis Bay tremendously.

Now that I have explored these topics I would like to ask the Minister about his confidence in Sinclair Knight and Partners Pty Ltd. I have long been wary of Sinclair Knight and Partners. Ninety per cent of its business is in engineering and about 10 per cent in environmental impact statements. It has a built-in conflict of interest in its operations as Four Corners and documents issued before that program have pointed out. Is the Minister still confident in Sinclair Knight and Partners? Is he still using it as the primary source of the environmental impact statement (EIS) material? At the end of the day, will he continue to use Sinclair Knight and Partners or will he perhaps seek some other inputs to the EIS?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, it is a matter of looking at what process we are faced with. I do not hire and fire the consultants employed by departments or companies in relation to the preparation of an environmental impact statement (EIS); that is entirely a matter for them. It is my job and my Department's job to ensure the integrity of the process by very carefully monitoring what they are doing and ensuring that it is adequate. The only comment I make about Sinclair Knight and Partners Pty Ltd-I am not in the habit of making comments about companies doing EISs; I do not think it appropriate that I do so-is that any suggestion that their participation will guarantee them additional work is simply not true. They have no contractural right to more work. Any other work that they may seek, be it as environmental consultants or in their capacity as an engineering firm, would have to be won by competitive tender, or at the very least by following the normal processes laid down for government purchase of services. So I do not think that suggestion is true. I will not comment on the adequacy or otherwise of companies, but I will comment on the adequacy or otherwise of the impact statement itself. Obviously, it is the view of my Department that more work needs to be done in the preparation of the draft; that has been made clear.

—I just draw the Minister's attention to the remark he made about the residents of the Jervis Bay area not wanting to have an armaments depot there any more than the residents of western Sydney want it in their area. Obviously, he has not read the Royal Australian Navy's brief. I am not surprised that he has not read it because he obviously has not had time for the Navy's position. The proposed site is inland and north-west of the bay and well removed from populated areas. If the Minister needs a map showing the location and its relationship with the populated areas, I am happy to provide him with one. The proposed ammunition depot is a long way away from any housing, apart from the odd farm on the road leading from the proposed depot to the proposed wharf. I mention that in passing because obviously the Minister did not know what he was talking about on that matter. I simply want to draw the Minister back to a face to face situation: is the Minister still of the view that it is most unlikely that the Navy can come up with an environmental impact statement that will satisfy the Federal Government?

TALK.START.PARA: —What has happened certainly suggests that it is very difficult. I cannot say that it is impossible, but it is difficult. That is why we have indicated that more work needs to be done. It is only appropriate to be honest about acknowledging difficulties rather than trying to hide them. Senator Baume made comments about houses in the area. I know where houses are in Jervis Bay, but I do not think Senator Baume understands that there are some people in Jervis Bay who think that the armaments depot located in Sydney is too close to them, let alone one placed on the north-west of the bay.

—I am certain that those residents will be greatly heartened by the Minister's great concern for their neuroses-obviously a far greater concern for their neuroses than for the welfare of the defence forces. I ask the Minister: Why are trespassers on the naval bombardment range not prosecuted when they persist with illegal entry?

TALK.START.PARA: —I could just as easily make an issue of why a great many people are not being prosecuted in the south-east forests of New South Wales by the New South Wales Government. Very often it is too difficult to pursue trespassers. The crime of trespass is not yet a hanging offence. It might be if Senator Baume had his way, but it is not at this stage. I am not sure whether it is worth the Defence Force's while. I have never asked the Services whether that is the reason, but the advisers are nodding, so it looks as though I have picked it. Having said that, I do not approve of the actions of many people who trespass on the Beecroft range, including Australian Democrats senators who have done so. I have said a number of times in here that, no matter what arguments we have for the protection of some very special areas around Jervis Bay, I cannot accept that the Beecroft range is one such area. I cannot accept that it is environmentally sensitive and I definitely do not accept the argument that it is an area of Aboriginal heritage. Having looked over a very long period at the Jervis Bay sites identified, there is really not an argument over the Beecroft range. That was a piece of sensationalism by a number of people; as some of them are my friends, I will not name them. We must look at environmental issues with a clear, cool and sane head. That does not mean that every area is worth the big argument-only some. In the Jervis Bay area, Beecroft range certainly does not come into the category of an area about which environmentalists should be arguing.

—I will be brief. As I was one of those who went out on the Beecroft range, I feel that perhaps I should explain our position. The point is that it is people's land; it is Aboriginal people's land and is significant to them. I went out on that range with an Aboriginal woman, a member of whose family had been killed in the early 1900s by an unexploded bomb, weapon or shell on the range. They grieve every time the shells hit that range. They suffer when the drum and drumsticks are hit by fire. The range is a remnant of a former time when the Royal Australian Navy had control over the area when HMAS Albatross was operating at full force. It is a kind of historic remnant that should not be there now. The whole area should be a national park. The undeveloped part of Jervis Bay should be a national park. I believe Senator Richardson is indicating in the negative and looking somewhat--
—You wouldn't put Beecroft in a national park?

—I could not quite hear what Senator Richardson said, but I do not think he agrees with my contention that it should be a national park. But it should be. The Navy has other areas that it can use for its shelling. It no longer needs that area to be contiguous to aircraft operations; there are other areas that it can shell. It is a unique area that should be preserved. The Navy has done a very good job and I give it full credit for stopping development in the Jervis Bay area. If the Navy had not had the control that it had, the place would be wall to wall condominiums. I give the Navy full credit for the job it has done in the past in preserving that area. But it is time for the Navy now to look at the greater good and say, `Yes, historically it was an accident that we had control of this area. We looked after it over those years but now, for the benefit of Australia, we will relinquish that control and give it over to national park status'. I mean a real national park-not one that will be subject to the whims of the New South Wales Government. But that is another issue. The point is that the Beecroft Peninsula is a very valuable area. It is worth saving in itself. Those who go out on the range to try to stop the bombardment do not do so just to be mischievous; they believe in their hearts that the bombardment should stop, and I too am of that opinion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief as I do not wish to debate the Beecroft range national park proposal at great length. Senator Sanders is someone who has fought for parks. An area has to be very special before I will go out and fight for it. It is true that the Royal Australian Navy has done a great job in maintaining Beecroft to the point that it is very often used for public recreational purposes, and I applaud that. National parks ought not to be those areas so modified by human behaviour. It is ludicrous to suggest that areas that have been bombed for 60 years are in some way pristine enough, good enough, to be national parks; they are just not. This is an area that is well looked after. I have no doubt that the Royal Australian Navy will continue to look after it well. I hope that it will continue to be used for recreational purposes, but that is not what national parks are about. What I am looking for as regards national parks, World Heritage areas and all the rest of it are those special parts of Australia that, hopefully, have not yet been greatly modified by human behaviour. If there is one form of human behaviour that modifies an area, it has to be bombing.

-I want to address another issue; that is, the letting of the Department of Defence contract for the maintenance of the Hercules fleet-a $20m contract-to New Zealand. I find it very difficult to understand why this has happened at a time of a national debt crisis, when Australia is spending $2 billion a month, or thereabouts, more than it is earning. To exacerbate the problem-I find this very difficult to understand-the Government has allowed a $20m defence contract to be given to a foreign country. I will listen very carefully to the Minister's explanation because I asked him a question on this matter last week and he was very evasive.
