TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am told that there is a submission before the New Zealand Cabinet and it has not yet dealt with it. We cannot really give any further advice on that. I am also informed that, if all this was to go ahead, some of the aircraft which would be used by New Zealand are aircraft that it already had, not aircraft sold to it by us. I am also informed that if this goes ahead we are paying half the cost, so it is not the case that we are hiring the aircraft involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. When he eventually gets the information and reveals it to us he might mention to us which of the aircraft are continuing New Zealand aircraft and which are Australian aircraft that have come back under different colours. My understanding is-I think the Minister's answer obfuscates this-that the great bulk of these aircraft came from Australia. In any event, as I understand it, they are to be rotated during the contract. The rotation arrangement under which New Zealand will be providing a service to Australia will mean that at some stage those aircraft sold to New Zealand which are serviceable, which have not crashed or been severely dealt with by the New Zealand pilots, will at some stage come back to provide this service. Sure, they will be supplemented by some A4s that the New Zealand Air Force already had, but I do not think the Minister's answer, which seeks to obfuscate the position, denies the fundamental point that the aircraft that will at some stage be servicing these requirements are aircraft we sold, very foolishly, to New Zealand.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish now to deal with what I understand to have been problems emerging from an existing contract for fleet support work with a Queensland company. What has been done to correct a situation where, as I understand it, the tenderer has failed to perform under the contract and has returned the contract? What expense has this been to the Commonwealth? What has been done to correct it? What penalties, if any, can be applied against the failed tenderer? What is happening in terms of assistance to the fleet in training, first, during this apparently lengthy delay until the A4s arrive and, secondly, as a result of the failure of the tender arrangement with the Queensland company?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously I reject this notion that aircraft were foolishly sold to New Zealand. I am advised that these aircraft used to be flown off HMAS Melbourne. It may have escaped Senator Michael Baume's notice, but it would be a bit difficult for them to continue to do so.
—They also flew out of Nowra, out of HMAS Albatross. They are very good ground support and good fleet support aircraft, as is demonstrated by the fact that you are leasing them again.

—We are not leasing them again. I made that point strongly, I thought, but Senator Baume did not pick it up. We certainly are not leasing them. The idea that in this day and age we still have some requirement for these aircraft on a full time basis, I put to Senator Baume, is foolish and that the decision to sell them was quite correct. In relation to Senator Baume's query about a contract with a Queensland company falling over, to overcome the difficulties caused the Government is continuing the previous contract while we go out to look for new bids.

—Once again I draw the Minister's attention to the document dated 23 August, signed by Mr Beazley-a direction to the Department of Defence asking it to arrange for suitable officers to undertake urgent discussions with Australian Airlines Ltd and Ansett Australia of Australia involving the Department of Transport and Communications to conclude arrangements to cover all aspects of the operation which subsequently has come to be known as Operation Immune. In view of the fact that the Minister refers in the document to the Commonwealth recovering from the airlines the full cost of operating these services and he does not advert to any other details, can we assume that the Government, at this stage at least, believed that the Defence Instructions (General) that existed on this subject was to be followed in all the details that he did not cover in the document of 23 August?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think one can make that assumption. The Minister was asking the Department of Defence and the Services to sit down and to negotiate with the Department of Transport and Communications and the airlines. I understand that they did so. Also, the Government was having discussions with the airlines. In any event, there was a full Cabinet discussion of this and a subsequent Government decision was made.
—Was the Minister aware of the Defence Instructions (General)?
—Yes.
—That was at the time that he prepared the minute of 23 August?
—I think the Minister would have been aware of this a long time before he wrote that. I hope so.

—I assume from that that the Minister's instruction about recovering full cost was consistent with the other details that were laid down in the Defence Instructions (General) and that he was not directing that that be overridden. Could the Minister advise when the Government, including the Department, began negotiating and/or when the airlines were advised of the full cost recovery policy as laid down in the document of 23 August?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The negotiations commenced in the days and weeks after the letter was written. As I have already said on a number of occasions, the Minister had told the Department to negotiate. As a result of those negotiations and of discussions that the Minister and others had with the airlines, there was the acknowledgment that I made earlier that a public service can sometimes involve a public cost and on this occasion it should. That meant that the instruction for full cost changed.
—When did the Government decide to alter the decision for full cost recovery?
—I cannot recall the date of the Government decision; but I will check and give it to Senator Newman fairly shortly. It was as a result of a Cabinet discussion.
—Can the Minister tell us why he believes that the public should bear the cost of providing this RAAF service to the airlines?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have answered that question tonight a number of times. I can also recall doing so in the Senate some weeks ago. The idea was not for the defence forces in any way to subsidise the operations of the airlines but rather to provide a service to the public-a public inconvenienced by the difficulties that we were having with the pilots. It seems to me that that is an appropriate form of assistance for the defence forces to make when a situation such as that arises. As I have said before, that is an extraordinary situation: not only does it not arise every day but I cannot recall a similar situation arising in living memory.

—The Minister says that it was extraordinary. It was extraordinary to the extent that the Government was calling out the troops; but it was not extraordinary in the sense that, at the time the decision was made, there was no suggestion, certainly in the public arena, that this would be continuing for so many weeks. I question the Minister's use of the word `extraordinary'. I further ask the Minister: Are the airlines not charging full economy fare? Are the airlines also not liable for either landing charges or navigation charges in the use of the RAAF civilian charters? Therefore, given the subsidised nature or the low cost of the charter per hour, are they probably not making a profit on the RAAF service?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am, Mr Temporary Chairman, as you are well aware, representing the Minister for Defence. I do not believe that I can give an answer to Senator Newman's question. I think it ought to be directed to whichever Minister represents the Minister for Transport and Communications in the appropriate Estimates committee.

—I thank the Minister for his response. But it was at the Estimates committee hearings for the Department of Transport and Communications that I found that nobody was paying landing charges or navigation charges on the charter of RAAF aircraft for civilian purposes. As they are State-registered aircraft, apparently no charge is levied. So the airlines, by chartering RAAF aircraft, are getting a free ride that they would never get were they chartering any other aircraft.
—The FAC's income suffers.

—That is correct. The public suffers again. The public is subsidising on each account. Just so that the Minister knows the facts, I am putting them on the record here. They are already on the public record from last week's Estimates committee hearings. I query why the public should continue to subsidise this profit-making situation. Has the Government found out how much the shortfall is between the costs and the revenue? Perhaps the Minister is not prepared to answer that question either.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have the information to answer it; that is why I am not prepared to answer it. If I can find out an answer at any point, I certainly will. Once again Senator Newman has used the phrase `the public suffers'. I think everyone would acknowledge that the role played by the defence forces during the last couple of months has been to make sure that the public does not suffer-or, at least, if there is any suffering, that it is minimised. They have been phenomenally successful in that role. That has been acknowledged by the thousands of people who have had the pleasure-and it is a pleasure-to ride on defence aircraft. My own experience, in particular one day on a Navy C130, is that I have never struck a friendlier or more cooperative crew.
—You didn't fly on a C130. You flew on a Navy 748.

—I am sorry; that is correct. They were terrific. I think that has been the experience of thousands of people. Australians are not walking round saying that the public have suffered because of the defence forces' role; rather, they are very grateful for the defence forces' involvement.

—If the Minister wants to get into a political debate that is removed from the Defence estimates, I am perfectly happy to demonstrate just how members of the public are suffering: they are suffering by paying full economy fares instead of discount fares-whether they are travelling on a Hercules or whatever. They are suffering because they will be required to subsidise, I presume, the Defence Department's deficit, which has been incurred because of the payment to the airlines. They are suffering because they will be subsidising the Federal Airports Corporation and the Civil Aviation Authority. They are suffering in every respect-in convenience and financially. Do not let the Minister try to tell us anything different. At least the way in which the Minister justifies his Government's action is on the public record. The public know that they are paying. The joys of travelling with `Hercair' may be great, but if Sir Peter Abeles and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had chosen to fly that way the dispute could have been over a lot quicker. If some of those on the other side of the chamber flew more frequently in those aircraft, marvellous though the Royal Australian Air Force and the Navy have been--
—Order! Perhaps we should go back to Defence rather than Transport.
—I would be happy to go back to Defence. In deciding that less than full cost recovery would be used, what criterion or formula was to be used?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot say what the `formula' was in that sense, because I am not sure whether I have an exhaustive list, but, as I think I outlined in this chamber some time ago, the airlines are providing some of the costs, such as fuel and ground handling costs, but were not recovering costs which in any case would have been borne by the Defence Department: capital costs, salaries, et cetera-that is, one would imagine, the more normal element of this. They are recovering an element of costs for spares and maintenance. I cannot yet say whether that recovery will be the total cost; that is yet to be determined. But I have said here before, and I think the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) has said, that the Department of Defence, if necessary, will be looking at a supplementation in its estimates later to make up the shortfall.
—In other words, the poor old taxpayer is paying again.
—For a public service.

—He is paying in every other area too. I just draw the Minister's attention to the fact that, if the airlines were chartering a civil aircraft, they would be contributing towards the salary and capital costs, so they are getting a free ride when they are chartering Royal Australian Air Force aircraft; there is no getting away from that fact. The public is subsidising the chartering of those aircraft. Can the Minister tell me whether the Cabinet decided those elements, or was it left to a negotiating team?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Cabinet made an overall decision, and I will not reveal the deliberations that led to that. I do not recall an exact figure being placed on that because, as I have just outlined, it was not possible to do so.
—Am I to understand from that answer that the Cabinet actually decided on the hourly rate per aircraft?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only go on my recollections of this and I certainly will not be reading Cabinet decisions into the record of Estimates committees. I have just said that the Cabinet made an overall decision and then made it clear that, if it was necessary for Mr Beazley to seek further assistance later, he would. Cabinet did not sit down as a group and negotiate with the airlines; that is obvious.

—I thank the Minister for his answer, but I am having a little trouble trying to work out the timetable. Did the Cabinet originally decide that there would be full cost recovery? I presume that the answer to that is yes, because that was the Minister's instruction on the twenty-third--
—No.

—That was the Minister's decision; he did not consult Cabinet on that? Am I right in thinking that he then sent off a negotiating team to meet with the airlines, who did not like full cost recovery, and a submission was then taken to Cabinet and Cabinet made a decision? Is that correct?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to check with the Minister as to whom he consulted at that very early point. I find it amazing that in all the honourable senator's comments about who suffers and who pays the bill, she cannot sheet home any of the blame to the greed of the pilots, who have caused this whole problem. Having said that, once the problem begins it is the job of government to look at how it can solve it. In doing so, at the very beginning of the dispute, the Minister quite correctly identified the defence forces as one means of easing public hardship and very quickly told the Chief of the Defence Force of his views on that. Subsequent to his laying down those views, there were consultations and negotiations with a whole range of people; and eventually Cabinet made a decision.
—Can the Minister advise who was in the negotiating team?

—No, I cannot. A number of departments were involved-Transport and Communications, Industrial Relations and our own Department. Negotiations were going on at different levels. I cannot nominate all of the meetings and all of the negotiations, no.
—In deciding that less than full cost recovery would be the option, were the ramifications or the precedents for future cost recovery of the use of defence assets considered?
—Yes.
—And disregarded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it is a question of their being disregarded; obviously, in any of these matters it is a question of a fine balance of judgment. The Government, confronted with the greed of the pilots and their insistence on a 30 per cent increase in wages, which had the potential through flow-ons to wreck the economy, obviously had to make some tough decisions. In doing so it had to consider the ups and downs, and did so. It came to a correct decision, which was to attempt to minimise public discomfort and suffering. That was the right way to go and was the way we went.

—I wish to draw to the attention of this chamber the very real concerns that I have on this matter, which I believe are evident from the line of questioning that I have been following today. The chamber should be aware that the Defence Instructions (General) require-they have the force of law-the Defence Force to follow certain procedures in the use of defence assets in assisting the civil community. They lay down that the Defence Force must either get full cost recovery or fulfil the requirements for waiving it. In this case the Defence Force did neither; therefore, I believe that the charges levied on the airlines, despite this document, which does not cut across that at all, are invalid and will have to be replaced and the airlines will have to reimburse the Defence Force for the full cost of the charters. I just put on the record that I have taken this matter to the Auditor-General and asked him to investigate. He has given me a verbal assurance that he will do so. It is in the light of that that I ask that all the documents relating to the Minister's directions to the forces be tabled in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave an indication some time ago about seeking the Minister's advice on the tabling of other documents. That was an extraordinary performance by Senator Newman. There is no question in anyone's mind, including hers, that the Minister for Defence and the Government can issue instructions to the Department of Defence-to the forces. Of course, that is what was done on this occasion. There is absolutely no doubt about that whatsoever. If the Minister wanted to make another instruction about this tomorrow afternoon, he could do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Irrespective of the Defence Instructions (General), to which the honourable senator was referring earlier, there is no doubt about the legal and constitutional capacity of the Minister for Defence to issue instructions. On this occasion the Minister issued an instruction; negotiations took place afterwards over quite a protracted number of weeks; there were Cabinet discussions and eventually a Cabinet decision; there were meetings between departments and between Ministers-all of which is the absolutely normal process of government going on at an abnormal time, when an extraordinary situation had developed because one group of pilots decided to hold our economy to ransom.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister now have the documents that have been asked for?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have some documents which I think Senator Newman wants. They are signed by Mr White, a Senior Private Secretary to the Minister, by the Minister himself and by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I table the documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to go back to the matter that Senator Newman was dealing with before the suspension of the sitting for dinner-namely, the actual amount by which the taxpayer is subsidising the airlines for each hour that the airlines use a government aircraft. In the replies to questions taken on notice, the Government advised us that under the agreement with the airlines, Defence is recovering an assessed amount per hour flown for spare parts and contractor maintenance but not for fixed costs such as salary costs, capital amortisation or overheads. The airlines are directly responsible for the provision of fuel, accommodation, meals and transfer costs for Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) aircrew and maintenance staff, ground handling, aircraft cleaning, in-flight rations and other minor miscellaneous expenditure. We were also told that the cost recovery rates per flying hour for spare parts and contractor maintenance-that is the total amount, apparently, to be claimed-for a 707 was $1,500 an hour. It was then stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The agreement between Defence and the airlines was set out in correspondence, which is currently under consideration for release under the FOI Act.
I am not certain what the state of that application is. Perhaps the Minister could let us know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Will Senator Baume make it clear to me exactly what correspondence he is referring to?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a reply to question on notice No. 90. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: What is the nature of the agreement between the airlines and the RAAF? Can it be made available?
I received the following reply to that question on notice:
The agreement between Defence and the airlines was set out in correspondence, which is currently under consideration for release under the FOI Act.
What is the state of that application and when is a decision likely to be made?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think the officers here can give me an answer to that question yet. I will have to make some further inquiries and I will endeavour to let Senator Baume know as soon as I can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. The reason this is very relevant is that Senator Newman was told, in response to question on notice No. 103 in which she asked for the hourly cost of a 707 to the Air Force, that the full running cost per hour is $12,031 as against a recovery rate of $1,500 an hour. It is true that not all of those costs would be capable of being recovered because the Air Force costs include petrol, oils and lubricants amounting to $1,983 an hour. Those costs are being paid for by the airlines themselves; they are providing the fuels, as I understand it. The airlines are directly responsible for the provision of fuel, among other minor items. So of that $12,031 we can take out petrol, oils and lubricants. We still have a figure of about $10,000 an hour.

SPEECH.PARA: It interests me to know how many other costs can be deducted from the $10,000 an hour. The cost to the Air Force of replacement spares when running these aircraft is assessed at $2,191 an hour, whereas the allowance for spare parts and contractor maintenance is set at only $1,500 an hour to the airlines. It would be rational if increased usage brought about a diminution in the hourly cost. Obviously, the longer an aircraft is used the less will be the impact on costs per hour. If that $2,191 an hour in replacement spares comes out instead at $1,500, we are still left with a contractor servicing cost of $2,953 an hour. If, in fact, the $1,500 an hour that the airlines are being charged is supposed to represent a combination of replacement spares and contractor servicing, which totals something like $5,000 an hour, I find it absolutely extraordinary that the economies of scale involved in greater usage because of the airline strike have, if you like, reduced the replacement spares and contractor servicing costs by something greater than one-third. It is simply untrue, I would think, that that would be the volume of the reduced incidence of costs per hour.

I am saying all these things to outline the need for the Government to come clean on these figures. Massive amounts of money per hour are involved. Look at the salary related costs: in-house maintenance costs amount to $851 an hour; crew costs amount to $888 an hour; salary related departmental administrative on-costs-and Senator Newman might be fascinated by this item-amount to $1,323. In other words, the salary related departmental administrative on-costs are 50 per cent more than the crew costs. This seems, once again, to reinforce the point that has been made by Senator Newman that it costs much more to administer an army than to have an army. It costs much more in administrative on-costs back at Russell Hill or somewhere than it costs actually to pay the crew. Maybe there is an explanation for this that will reveal all. Then, non-salary related departmental administrative on-costs amount to $883 an hour. We have something like over $2,200 an hour on various departmental administrative on-costs-one salary, one non-salary. On top of that, we have $959 in capital costs per hour. Allowing for economies of scale on some of the other items, it is evident that the Air Force is picking up a bill probably of about $8,000 an hour. The Air Force is still picking up about $8,000 an hour for the hours during which the aircraft are being used by the airlines. As well, the Government is being paid $1,500 an hour. So, every hour these Air Force planes are in the air, there is a loss per hour of about $8,000. That is the sort of cost that Senator Newman was talking about. It is the cost to the taxpayer.

It is about time that Senator Richardson realised that when he talks about the cost to the Australian public of the airlines dispute basically he is talking about the cost to a relatively small proportion of the Australian public who are consistent users of airlines and who have been massively inconvenienced by the arrogant activity of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, equally matched by the arrogant behaviour of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It takes two to tango. In this matter, the Prime Minister has behaved with no less arrogance than the Federation of Air Pilots or, it seems, the employers. It is only right, now that these figures have been revealed, for the Government and the Minister to indicate whether it is correct that the defence forces have to directly subsidise the airline companies by about $8,000 an hour when they use a 707. When does the Government intend to work out what the cost to the Australian Defence Force has been? As I understand it, the timetable is for these aircraft to be withdrawn by Christmas.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fifteenth of next month.
—By 15 December. I would be grateful if the Minister could give us any assistance with this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I explained to Senator Newman earlier, all of these costs are fixed costs which we would have been paying anyway. So we do not regard that as a problem. The main point Senator Baume is missing out on is that these costs are predicated on the basis of a normal year for a 707 in our service. That normally works out at 250 hours a year. That is what the costs are based on. In the space of just two months, to the middle of this month, they have flown 540 hours, which is an extraordinary difference and which must have a substantial bearing on the costs which have been supplied to Senator Baume as a result of the question on notice. So when one takes into account that quite massive operational difference, it must have a proportionate effect on the costs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before dinner I addressed a question to the Minister. I mentioned that the Defence Department contract for the maintenance of the Hercules fleet of aircraft in Australia had gone to New Zealand. The Minister informed me that the contract had not been let. I then asked the Minister whether any person in the Australian companies that tendered for that contract had been advised that the contract had been awarded to New Zealand. The Minister responded that no-one had been so advised. I found that strange, and I contacted people in the Hawker Pacific aviation company. They sent me a press release which said:

SPEECH.PARA: In response to verbal advice from the Department of Defence that a contract for maintenance of RAAF C130s Hercules aircraft is to be placed with Air New Zealand Hawker de Havilland.

If the Minister is playing semantics and saying that the contract has not been let but that it has informed Hawker de Havilland that it will not get the contract, that it has been awarded to New Zealand, then the Minister is misleading the Committee. Hawker de Havilland would not have put out this press release unless it had been informed by the Department of Defence that that contract had gone to a company outside Australia. I point out the seriousness of this matter to the Minister. I note that he has not intentionally misled the Senate but obviously he has got the wrong advice. I note that the Minister has asked his adviser, who is checking. We might be able to leave the matter until that advice is received.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly was not trying to play semantics or fiddle with words. There are two points. The first relates to the contract itself. No contract has been let until the Minister has approved and announced it. I am advised that he has not. So I cannot play with words over that. Secondly, I rechecked with the adviser who was here regarding the question of whether anyone in the industry was advised that a contract was about to be let to a New Zealand outfit. He repeated that in so far as he was aware, no. But he has gone to check with the officer who gave the actual advice at the time that Senator Boswell asked the question before dinner. If Senator Boswell could give me the indulgence of a few minutes I will try to get to the bottom of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I turn to another matter. A point is made in the Estimates Committee D report to the Senate that members of the Committee directed a significant number of questions on matters of fact to the Department in advance of the hearing and that the Department took a large number of further questions on notice at the hearing. The report made the following point:

SPEECH.PARA: While recognising the workload associated with answering these questions, the Committee considered the Department should be capable of more rapid response. Most, if not all, of the questions related to matters of fact and the requirement of a department to answer such questions from Estimates committees is a predictable feature of the Public Service routine. The Committee expects prompt and full answers to the questions of fact that its members direct to the Department.

One question which I asked, and which prompted a response that was wrong-surprisingly, especially as the response came from the Minister-was whether the services are acting as agents for the airlines in their activities. I wanted to know whether any negligence involved in any accidents, for example, would involve a claim on them by a passenger. Senator Richardson responded:

I think that all I can say in answer to Senator Baume-and obviously I would have to have this checked with some superior legal advice to mine-is that I would imagine that anyone flying on Air Force planes at the moment is contracting not with the Air Force but with the airlines through which they booked the ticket. I would imagine that any action they would have for some injury that might befall them would be against the airline. But we would have to check that.

The thing that interested me was that at the Estimates Committee hearing it was asserted that it was not known, that that advice had not been looked into at the time the deal was done with the airlines about providing aircraft. Yet the written response that I get is that the established legal position was confirmed prior to setting up the arrangements for Defence Force assistance to the airlines. It does not say by whom it was confirmed. Perhaps the defence forces were not aware that it had been confirmed.
The following response was provided to a question asked in the Senate Estimates Committee:

Claims by passengers or their dependants arising from injury or death in the course of carriage by Defence Force aircraft are covered by the Air Accidents (Commonwealth Government Liability) Act 1963. The general effect of that Act, which applies the Civil Aviation (Carriers Liability) Act 1959 to such carriage, is that the Commonwealth is liable as operator of the aircraft without proof of negligence but subject to a statutory upper limit of $100,000 for the claims in respect of each casualty.

In other words, the Commonwealth has been accepting a very large insurance risk, if you like, over the many thousands of people it has been carrying in defence service aircraft. That intrigues me, because I would have imagined that the private carriers would be paying insurance premiums to cover such insurance risk. Here is another hidden cost that the private carriers have been relieved of by this generous Government-I suppose, in the circumstances, I could say, `From a great height', as they are up in the air. It disturbs me that here we have another instance of a hidden subsidy. I do not know what the size of the subsidy is, because I presume that the Commonwealth does not insure for these kinds of risks. That is the normal style. I ask the Minister whether, in view of the special risk being undertaken, special private insurance was taken out and, if so, whether the airlines were charged with this cost that they would otherwise have to face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now want to deal very briefly with responses to questions that both Senator Newman and I asked during the Estimates hearings about the rights of the Minister to alter the arrangements under which aircraft were provided for carrying passengers in aid of a civilian situation. I asked in particular, whether there were any limits on the powers of the Minister to make orders relating to the defence forces being used for non-defence purposes. The question I asked was:

SPEECH.PARA: What are the limits to instructions that can be issued by the Minister for the ADF?
Basically, the simple response was that there are not any, except those set by the Constitution. I must say that this struck me as being of concern. The reply says:
1. a. Section 8 of the Defence Act (consistently with established constitutional practice) vests the general control and administration of the Defence Force in the Minister;
b. Command of the Defence Force and the arms of the Defence Force under s 9 of the Defence Act is exercised subject to and in accordance with any directions of the Minister;
I accent that-`any directions of the Minister'. It continues:

c. Section 9a of the Defence Act empowers the Secretary of the Department and the Chief of the Defence Force to jointly have the administration of the Defence Force, subject to the powers of the Minister in s 8.

2. On the question of whether there are limits to the instructions the Minister can give, the Minister can give instructions in relation to the control and administration of the Defence Force which are within the powers of the Executive Government under the Constitution. Accordingly, the Minister for Defence can provide directions for the exercise of the command and administrative powers over the Australian Defence Force provided those directions are themselves in accordance with the Constitution and the laws of the Commonwealth. In practice, additional constraints on the powers of the Minister for Defence would include the policies of the Government . . .

That is a bit of a whimsy; this Government's policies do not appear to rest heavily on the precept that strike breaking and the use of the defence forces to break strikes is part of its policies, but that is for the Government to determine. Apparently, that provision imposed no constraint on this Government. The reply continues:
. . . of which he is a member, the conventions of the Cabinet system and his accountability to Parliament.

A Minister's accountability to parliament is all very well if Parliament knows what he has done. Parliament has not been able to find out what the Minister for Defence has done. We have had to ask inch by inch and batter our way through a wall of silence to find out what has been done. If the Department is going to provide us with answers saying that the accountability of the Minister is one of the very few constraints on a Minister's activities, and this Government does not tell us what is happening, then I believe we are in a very serious constitutional position.

Senator Newman has only recently received a letter that states that the Minister had said he wanted full cost recovery. I think that was in August. He is the Minister. With the Government apparently taking a different view, we do not find out specifically what directions have been given. In response to a question I asked about 10 minutes ago, we were told by the Minister, `We cannot let you know that; a freedom of information request is in. We do not know whether we can let you know exactly what the instructions are, as we have not made up our minds about it'. It seems to me that this is a serious matter of basic principle. If the basis on which the Minister is at all limited in the exercise of his power to do anything or to issue any directions and his accountability to the Parliament is one of the constraints, then this Government has just totally shown its contempt for the Parliament by not providing this kind of detail.

In that sort of context the sorts of concerns expressed by Air Vice-Marshal Collings, retired, about the unlimited capacity of the Government to instruct the Defence Force to do anything, despite the Defence Force's regulations, and to ignore or overrule those regulations, seem to me to be very real. Following my questions of Admiral Beaumont before Estimates Committee D, Air Vice-Marshal Collings wrote to me, saying:

Firstly, there is a basic contradiction in Adm Beaumont's reply: he starts by saying that the relevant Defence instructions are `simply self-imposed instructions within the Department of Defence.' He then concludes by saying that `the instructions to which the Air Vice Marshal was referring were, in fact, derived through the authority and power of the Minister, and not by any other means.' You will note that in my letter I specifically said that the Instructions are issued on the authority of the Minister.
He therefore takes exception to the admiral's statement that he, Air Vice-Marshal Collings, was not aware of the origin of these departmental instructions. The key point in the letter is as follows:

The first argument was that the Minister could override or vary the requirements of the Defence Instructions as the instructions are self-imposed administrative rules. I have no argument with the first part of this statement but of course in such a serious matter as the pilot's dispute, one would expect that the Minister's accountability to the public would require a public statement on the matter.
I could not agree more. He continues:

. . . if it is a special case then the public deserves to know why the actions by the Minister go against the general caution in the instructions with respect to use of the ADF in industrial disputes.

There is no doubt in my mind that what happened went against the general instructions because of the obsession of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) with this strike and his determination to break the union for whatever purpose he had. I must say that I agree with what Air Vice-Marshal Collings says in another letter, as follows:

We seem to have a situation where expert opinion in this country thinks that because the use of the ADF in this dispute is popular with a large section of the public then the consequences are unimportant, where this is far from the case.

In the absence of any official statements on the matter I must assume certain facts. Firstly, the dispute is not considered a national emergency or the ADF would have been `called out' by an order of the Governor-General-in-Council. One would certainly expect to have been appraised publicly of such a serious action by the Government-wouldn't one? The use of the ADF must therefore be on the basis of assistance of a non-emergency nature to the civil community. . . If that is so, then the full cost of the operation should have been recovered or the public purse would have been used to unfairly advantage one section of the community.

I know that all these issues have been raised before. All I want to say is that the action taken by the Government imposes on it a special requirement to come clean, and this Government has failed to do so; it has ducked it. The only information is information that has been teased and weaselled out of it. We are still waiting for the terms of the deal. We are still waiting to find out why this Government has broken the ADF's own rules. I believe that this is a matter of major principle, and it would be very nice if the Government could at last come clean.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter relating to the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits (DFRDB) Act arrangements for service personnel. I refer specifically to a letter that I have received from the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Simmons) in response to representations that I made to him. I will do so without referring to the former serviceman's name because that is not specifically relevant. I want to know whether this is a situation that arises frequently. In his letter the Minister refers to my representations and goes on to point out that any member who re-enters the Defence Force has the opportunity to elect to repurchase into the scheme for his or her past service, the cost being generally 5.5 per cent of the salary on re-entry for each year of service purchased. He goes on to comment about the arrangements for payment back and says:

SPEECH.PARA: Such purchase enhances the benefit on age retirement and allows for the payment of pension on retirement with less than 20 years current service.

All members who purchase past service have the potential to benefit from that action and it is for that reason that the DFRDB Act requires that payment be completed in all cases and any amount outstanding on discharge becomes a debt to the Commonwealth and must be recovered.
This is the point that I wish to raise. He goes on to say:
Those who are classified Class B who are discharged with less than 23 years of service on Class A are in this category.
He says that they do not gain any advantage from this and then says:
However neither the member nor his service could foresee the invalidity discharge. The member presumably took such a possibility into account before electing to purchase his past service.

It seems to me to be patently absurd to suggest that anyone who had been in the Services but left and then went back would be doing so foreseeing the possibility of invalidity. He then goes on to deal with the facts of the case in particular, which I will present to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), who is at the table, so that he will understand precisely what I am talking about. He says that this man served from 12 April 1966 to 11 April 1972 and re-entered on 17 February 1981. He continues:

He elected on 20 July 1981 to purchase his six years past service. He was paying this off at $15.70 per fortnight. He had paid some $1789 by the time he was discharged on invalidity grounds on 28 February 1986. A further $3328 was outstanding.

Of course, he is being pursued for that now that he has left the service. This is not quite in the same category as the $20m that the Minister was talking about a short while ago, but it is very big money to my constituent. The Minister continues:

. . . was originally classified as Class C, which entitled him to a refund of his contributions, including the amount he paid for his past service. In addition, he was entitled to an additional payment equal to half his total contributions. This additional payment included an amount equal to half the payment still owing for the purchase of his past service. There was no point in requiring him to make payment of the outstanding debt at that time as it would have been immediately refunded to him. Mr . . . received full recognition of his past service in Class C benefit.

Mr . . . sought reconsideration of the Class C decision and on 21 November 1988 the Administrative Appeals Tribunal set aside the decision and classified him as Class B from the date of discharge. As a result of that decision Mr . . . receives a Class B pension. The Class C benefit already paid was recovered from the arrears of pension due to him.
It is unfortunate that Mr . . . was discharged on invalidity grounds-
that is an understatement; it is unfortunate-
and classified at a level where he did not benefit from his earlier decision to purchase his past service.
How the Act could be worded in such a way as to potentially penalise any serviceman in that fashion is beyond me. The Minister continues:
Nevertheless I confirm that Mr . . . is required to pay the amount outstanding at his discharge to finalise the purchase of his past service.

He then goes on to give what the Authority considers is the appropriate rate of payment at which he may pay, et cetera, and says that if he feels a lower rate of recovery is appropriate he should speak to the Authority. The Minister concludes in the last paragraph by saying that he trusts that this has clarified the matter for my constituent. I can tell the Committee that it did not clarify it for my constituent and it certainly did not clarify it for me. I cannot believe that the Minister, knowing that the Act penalises servicemen in this fashion, does not do something about it. Knowing that, I cannot believe that he does not take the appropriate step to make an ex gratia payment to expunge the debt when he says in his letter that clearly the officer has received no benefit from it.

My constituent received a letter dated 22 December 1988 setting out his entitlements as a consequence of his discharge and indicating the rate of fortnightly repayment thereafter. There was no mention whatever of paying any money back to him. Subsequently, in March, to my constituent's astonishment, he got a letter saying, `It has come to our attention that at the time of your discharge you were purchasing previous service under section 89 of the Act'. It went on to give the total cost of the purchase, stated that he had paid so much and still owes $3,000-odd. It then stated, `As this amount represents a debt due and payable to the Commonwealth, I have no alternative but to request that your remittance for the above amount be forwarded'. There was absolutely no explanation in this letter as to how this came about. I am sure honourable senators can imagine how somebody would feel on receiving such a letter. I suggest that the letter could have been worded much better. He could at least have been invited in to have explained to him what had happened and why the money was owing, if it is possible to give an explanation of that.

The Minister implies in his letter that this happens quite frequently. I would like to know whether it does happen frequently and how many people have been affected by this and have had to pay back what are considerable amounts of money long after they have been discharged and thought they were getting on with their lives in a different fashion having had to leave the Services on the ground of invalidity. How many current cases are there? Why does the Minister not seek the authority either to amend the Act or at least to give him some discretion as to whether he persecutes servicemen in this fashion or gives them some chance to get on with their lives?

TALK.START.PARA: —I now want to turn to the frigate contract. This is a long and involved matter. There is no doubt that the Federal Government has something of a debt to pay to the New South Wales Government because the enormous activity of the New South Wales Government in supporting the Australian Warships Systems (AWS) tender meant that the competition presented to Australian Marine Engineering Consolidated Ltd (AMECON) encouraged a much lower price than might otherwise have been the case. As it was, the AMECON tender was about $350m less than the AWS tender. The New South Wales Government activity resulted in massive pressure being brought to bear on AMECON to ensure that a fair proportion of the work would be done in New South Wales even though the New South Wales tender had not been successful. The result is that an offer of about $1,200m of work has been made to New South Wales, including about $700m for Newcastle.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, the contract between the Commonwealth and AMECON was signed on the tenth of this month. But it is also understood that the contract places no binding obligation on AMECON to put work in Newcastle or New South Wales. As I understand it, the only overall obligation is to meet an Australia and New Zealand industry involvement target of 80 per cent. Letters of commitment from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) have been sent to New South Wales reiterating the claims made by AMECON about placement of work in New South Wales and a Cabinet subcommittee has been nominated to oversee the project and to maximise opportunities in the Hunter. That subcommittee is made up of Messrs Beazley and Morris and Senator Button. However, when the Defence Department Deputy Secretary, Dr McIntosh, appeared before the Senate Estimates Committee he stated that the Defence Department could not give any firm guarantees as to the level of work that Newcastle or New Zealand would get from the Anzac ship project. He also said that the Federal Government could, if it wanted to, approve the removal of work if there were sufficient reasons, such as significant industrial disputes or large cost increases.

The New South Wales Government has written to, and sought clarification and assurances from, the Prime Minister, the Minister for Defence and members of the Cabinet subcommittee. The Deputy Premier of New South Wales and the Chairman of the Hunter Economic Development Council have written and, as I understand it, no satisfactory guarantees have been made in response to those letters. Now that the South Australian election is out of the way and any questions of allocating goodies in South Australia will no longer be an election issue, I suppose we have to recognise that a Federal election will be coming up early in the next year. As most of the marginal seats in the coming Federal election appear to be in Melbourne, no doubt the Government could well have political objectives in being fairly relaxed about whether it will stick by its undertakings to Newcastle in particular, and New South Wales in general, that they will get their share of the contract, particularly as absolutely no guarantees have been given.

Quite frankly, this Government cannot keep treating Newcastle with contempt or it will find that there will be the same sort of response at the next Federal election from the Newcastle region that there was at the State election. I confidently expect swings of up to 15 per cent against Labor if this Government keeps up its arrogant disregard of Newcastle and the Hunter region which is evident in its treatment of the region on this frigate matter. It is about time that some hard and fast guarantees were given about the work.

This offer of about 40 per cent of the Australian contract work for New South Wales has been made on several occasions and was reaffirmed by AMECON on 11 October. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the letters from Mr Beazley and Mr Hawke to the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Greiner, on these matters.

Dear Premier Greiner
Thank you for your letter of 11 August 1989 signed jointly with Mr Bob Carr, Mr Michael Easson, and Alderman John McNaughton supporting the NSW-based AWS bid for the ANZAC Ship Project.

As you are aware, the AMECON consortium has been selected as the successful tenderer for the ANZAC Ship Project. I can assure you that this decision was made on merit and reflected the unanimous conclusions reached by the Chief of Naval Staff's Advisory Committee and the Defence Force Development Committee. You will be aware that the Chief of Naval Staff, Vice Admiral Hudson, has publicly stated the Navy's total satisfaction with the MEKO 200 design and emphasised that the Navy decision to recommend selection of AMECON was independent and preceded further higher committee consideration.

The Government has from the outset fully recognised the important role which the project would be able to play in promoting the restructuring and development of Australian industry. We have consistently stated that price and industry participation would be key factors in the tender decision.

Both consortiums offered excellent designs and industry participation packages. The AMECON tender was, however, $350m lower than the AWS bid. As you would appreciate, this margin far exceeds the two percent cost differential which you nominated in our meeting on 4 August as an acceptable premium for placing the ANZAC Ship contract with the Newcastle-based consortium for regional development purposes.

I would take this opportunity to emphasise that NSW, and the Hunter region in particular, stands to benefit greatly from the ANZAC Ship tender decision. Under the AMECON bid, $700m will need to be invested in Newcastle industry and some 1,200 jobs will be created there. AMECON plans to build 58 hull sections and assemble and launch 5 of the twelve ships built at Newcastle. Overall, NSW will have about 40% of the industry work in Australia, matching the level of work going to Victoria. The share of work going to NSW stands to approach 50% in the event that New Zealand decides not to participate in the Project.

On 18 August, after the Government's selection of the AMECON tender, I had useful and constructive discussions in Canberra with the Lord Mayor of Newcastle, Alderman McNaughton. I can assure you, as I assured Alderman McNaughton at our meeting, that the Federal Government is committed to working in full cooperation with the New South Wales Government to develop proposals for the advancement of the Hunter region.

The Government looks forward to a continuation of the bi-partisan approach which characterised the lead-up to the decision on the frigate project. I am confident that NSW will admirably meet the challenges of participation in this major defence project and that work on the ANZAC ships will do much to develop Newcastle as an important shipbuilding centre into the next century.
I have written in similar terms to Mr Carr and Mr Easson and have discussed these issues with Alderman McNaughton.
Yours sincerely
R. J. L. Hawke

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the chamber. There is no question about the guarantees. For example, the Minister for Defence wrote in September this year saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Although it did not secure the prime contract, Newcastle will gain enormously from its share of the project work.
Newcastle `will gain', not `may gain'. The Minister continued:

The project will bring to Newcastle a full range of shipbuilding skills, not only the traditional steel fabrication work. Other areas in NSW will also benefit and the State will receive about 40% of the work in Australia on the project.

It is getting close to the `money up or shut up' stage. The money has not turned up yet. The contracts have been signed and, as I have said, I understand that there are no guarantees in those contracts about the volume of work coming to New South Wales. I would take this opportunity to emphasise that New South Wales, and the Hunter region in particular, stands to benefit greatly from the ANZAC Ship tender decision. Under the bid . . . $700m will need to be invested in Newcastle industry and some 1,200 jobs will be created there.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the chamber. I restate that the contract between AMECON and the Commonwealth places no obligation on AMECON to put work in Newcastle or New South Wales. TALK.START.PARA: —The first point I would like to make in response to Senator Michael Baume is that, when we take into consideration all the subcontractors who have had to deal with AMECON in the preparation of its bid, we have to remember that AMECON has had to go out and seek competitive bids from a whole range of subcontractors and make its decisions before it comes to the Government. All of that having been done, these subcontractors are under a contractual obligation to AMECON to perform. On the assumption that each and every subcontractor performs, I do not see any problem at all. Nothing would change in AMECON's intentions and every bit of the promised percentage to Newcastle would go to Newcastle. But it would not be responsible, let alone proper, for the Government to insist that each and every part of the subcontractor work takes place with the intended subcontractor if that company could not perform. In a massive contract like this, one cannot deny that it is imaginable that some will not perform, be it for whatever reason-industrial relations obviously being one.

SPEECH.PARA: That does not all work to make one think that in some way Newcastle might suffer. It could well be that the Victorian or South Australian components of this contract do not perform and that more work will need to be sent to New South Wales. There is no guarantee that any inability to perform has to be in Newcastle. Like Senator Michael Baume, as a New South Wales senator I have faith in the Newcastle end of this business holding up its end, performing creditably and delivering on its promises. That being the case, none of us has a worry. In the Estimates hearing of 10 October Dr McIntosh, in referring to AMECON, said:

It had gone out and got bids from subcontractors all around Australia and New Zealand and overseas for those parts and its tender was based on those costs. The expectation quite clearly was if those costs were maintained by the subcontractors and they were firmly bid to the winner, that is where they would stay. That is the basis on which the contract is being drawn up.
Further to that, when talking about the main contract, he said:
He would have to put in a contract change proposal to make those changes and we-
the Government-
would have to agree to the contract change proposal.

That places AMECON in a very difficult position if it is choosing to walk away from any part of the work. Dr McIntosh's answer in response to a question from Senator Baume is pretty relevant to what Senator Baume is talking about now. Senator Baume said:
I have been advised that Transfield, for example, has no contractual obligation whatsoever to undertake the proportion outlined in Newcastle or even in New South Wales.
Dr McIntosh said:
That `whatsoever' I would not agree with. It has no absolute requirement, but it certainly has quite a strong requirement to do it.

What Senator Baume was told then still applies. What is more of concern to me tonight is that AMECON-Senator Baume referred in his question to Transfield Engineering, but AMECON is a bit more than just Transfield, so I will refer to it rather than Transfield-has shown not the slightest hint that it wants in any way to walk away from promises it has made to the Newcastle end of the deal. I have had some talks with AMECON. Like many members from New South Wales, I have had representations from, for example, the Lord Mayor of Newcastle, not to mention people such as Allan Morris, the honourable member for Newcastle. Because of those representations I have subsequently spoken to some people from AMECON to ask them what their intentions were. They have made it very clear to me that all the undertakings they have given the Government about what work will be done in New South Wales and what percentage of it will be done in Newcastle will be kept. They saw no problems with them and were proceeding along the lines they had indicated.

So let us not attempt to talk up some withdrawal of what Newcastle will get. It would seem to me that Newcastle will get the work but, as in any other part of Australia or indeed New Zealand, if a company in Newcastle cannot perform, AMECON would have the right to approach the Government about going somewhere else. But, given the faith that I have in Newcastle, that may well mean that, as contractors fall down in other places, the Newcastle percentage of this contract will be increased rather than decreased.

Secondly, and in particular, the New South Wales Labor movement, particularly under Michael Easson, has been totally and completely cooperative and responsible in its response to this whole project-far more so than has been evidenced in Victoria. Newcastle has been through its traumas. They are well and truly over. There is a spirit of cooperation and determination in Newcastle that, quite frankly, does not exist at Williamstown to my knowledge. My impression is that a lot of the scars of the recent disputes in Williamstown are still there. There is a more cooperative and progressive work force in Newcastle. I think it recognises the changed direction. I believe it is absolutely vital to the morale of that work force that something more positive than the assurances that have been given take place, by way of either contractual statement or something else. But I take the Minister's point about assurances from AMECON rather than from Transfield. I beg the pardon of Mr Belgiorno Nettis. He had also given an assurance that he would stick by the Newcastle commitments. I do not believe that I am just being like Oliver Twist, asking for more. I think the Newcastle work force deserves a greater sense of commitment than is given in the statements that have been made.

I have some other problems with this contract, relating to the $350m price difference. As I understand it from Senate Estimates, it was the price difference which was the essential difference between the two tenders and all other things were held to be equal. I have some problems about that, too. I want an assurance that when the contract was signed it was for the original price. I have heard a lot of rumours of something like a $400m price rise, one way or another. If that has taken place, it would raise serious questions about the merit of that tender price. Perhaps we can look into that.

There is another question to be answered. It relates to Blohn and Voss, who have retained Signaal to advise and assist in design issues surrounding the integration of equipment into the Anzac frigate. The Swedish Government has asked Ferranti of the United Kingdom and PEAB, which is now BEAB, to advise it on the design of the combat system, the quality of which in relation to the Anzac ship specifications is now apparently of great concern to the Swedish Government.

AMECON offered the BEAB combat system after positive guidance, as I understand it, by Defence officials during the tendering process because the system AMECON preferred, which, I understand, was Sintacs, was ruled out by Defence on cost capability grounds. I now understand that the PEAB system, which has already been of questionable relevance to a frigate, has failed on a Norwegian ship and, as a result, the Swedish Government has selected Ferranti of the United Kingdom to assist the now BEAB to redesign the system.

There is a question to be answered here. Maybe it can be resolved satisfactorily. I am concerned that there is, perhaps, evidence of Australia entering into a contract with an unproven and perhaps even now failed combat system, that is, unproven in terms of AMECON, and that this technical risk is a little compounded by the Commonwealth not insisting that Blohn and Voss be part of, or a shareholder in, the prime contractor. I ask the Minister to respond on these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall endeavour to do so. I am just getting some particular advice from Dr McIntosh. I will talk about the things the honourable senator first raised until I get an answer on those last points. I am more politically and socially inclined to Michael Easson than I am to John Halfpenny-quite considerably so over a long period. If asked about the industrial attitudes of the two labour councils over time, I would not surprise the honourable senator by saying that I would opt for New South Wales very strongly.
—How would you like John Halfpenny in the Senate?

—I would welcome any colleague from Victoria. As soon as he got here he would probably knock one of you lot off and I would be delighted. Senator Baume mentioned that he thinks the scars of recent disputes are still in Williamstown. To be fair to John Halfpenny, who I think behaved very responsibly in this exercise, and to the Victorian unions, the industrial package which was achieved at Williamstown was a landmark package for Australian industrial relations. I do not think I could suggest even by implication to Senator Baume or to the Senate that it was lacking. I believe that that agreement will stand the test of time. In another category, which has nothing to do with Anzac ships, but with the Antarctic ship which I am trying to have built at Carringtons, there was a four-day strike there a few days ago. So not everyone in Newcastle does what we would like, even though I have the highest regard for Carringtons.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that Senator Baume does not fall victim to a tendency being shown by a number of his colleagues on other matters, and that is of believing or parroting the line given to him by the losers in any contract battle. This one was very hard fought. In the weeks leading up to the decision, like Senator Baume I was lobbied by AMECON and by AWS. They were beating paths to my door, to other Ministers' doors, to Premiers' doors and all the rest of it. I took the opportunity of noting down all the complaints that AMECON made to me. I actually had a briefing from Defence prior to the Cabinet decision. I think Admiral Beaumont and Dr McIntosh were the two people who came to see me. I put to them many of the points put to me-the facts, to hark back to a debate yesterday-by the AWS group. But these facts turned out not to be facts, or to be non-facts, when examined. The main thrust of the AWS line was that in some way this was a vastly inferior ship. Certainly they were able to allay my fears as to whether that was true. So I had no problems with the decision to go ahead with an AMECON bid.

When one looks at the factors that weighed most heavily in the minds of the Cabinet in making that decision, I think I was typical of all the members of the Cabinet in that certainly we felt that the price differential-given what I said to the honourable senator earlier, which is that there was no great difference between the two vessels-was just too great for us to walk away from. But the $350m, which was certainly an apples versus apples comparison, was if anything underdone by Defence. In an effort to ensure that no-one could query the absolute use of discretion by Defence, the absolute lack of bias by Defence, it bent over backwards to give AWS a fair go. On my reading of the figures, certainly the $350m was way under what I thought the difference was. In any event, the $350m difference has been increased to a $500m difference on the signing of the contract by the choosing of some cheaper options.

The honourable senator mentioned this PEAB system, which was selected on an existing system, so that one could actually see how it was in operation, compared with the alternative, which was not in operation. So, it had nothing to do with cost capability. I am advised that we are unaware of any combat system failure with this system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it then, the signed contract is now clearly $150m less than the original one and that indicates that these rumours that there had been a $400m escalation are simply rumours and unfounded. Nonetheless, I think that some of the things seem to be of such moment that it is better to get them out of the way.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the PEAB system, what concerns me is that I have been under the impression that this combat command and control equipment and systems-which is probably the highest value area of the contract, valued at $900m for eight ships-could be in some kind of doubt in relation to its design and performance. I understand from the Minister's earlier response that there are no doubts and that he has heard no comments that it is critical. I must say that I am interested in that, because the information I was given was that the Swedish Government did have some concern, together with the fact that the actual system needed to meet specification is nowhere near in existence and, at best, there is only one derivative on a Danish inshore patrol boat. I assume from the shaking of the head that that is also a furphy.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is being treated with some derision.

—I thank the Minister for that. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. I am always concerned about the scope for escalation in contracts. We are sitting in a building which is the classic example of escalation of costs in contracts. In fact, the Department of Defence is aware of escalation in contracts. To what extent are there special arrangements in this contract which will in fact prevent the sorts of escalations that we have seen in so many of these Defence Department contracts?

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously we have to guard against them. In the case of the contract the honourable senator is referring to now, Williamstown dockyard was owned and operated by the Government and not performing brilliantly.

—I am trying to be polite at this late hour, but not performing too well. Also, there was a cost plus contract. It was not fixed price. In this case, pretty well every element of this contract is fixed price. Obviously there is some allowance for exchange rate variations, and it is always possible to have some big variations there, but nothing of the order that the honourable senator is speaking of in that other contract. With the change in the situation at Williamstown, I would imagine that the impetus for the big cost increase would be gone anyway, even if it were not a fixed price contract. I think if that same contract were run through again we would do very much better.

—A problem that seems to emerge from the Blohn and Voss problem is that, as I understand it, the Commonwealth has not yet seen the nature of the contract between Australian Marine Engineering Consolidated Ltd (AMECON) and its now subcontractor design agent, Blohn and Voss. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

The reality is that there is no such thing as a fixed price contract in this business, no matter what the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) says. TALK.START.PARA: —One of the things that certainly impressed me about the AMECON bid-and I am sure that it had a similar effect on my Cabinet colleagues-was the quality of documentation and the comparison between it and that offered by the competitor. There was no doubt that the documentation received from AMECON showed that the AMECON consortium had a much more detailed grasp of this contract than did its opponents. AMECON provided a document of some 3,000 pages of the most detailed cost breakdown to provide the Commonwealth with a cost control system.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member has said, there is always provision for variation in contracts, and I do not read too often of their being varied down; it is always up. However, a variation would require the agreement of the two parties. By going into the very detailed specifications that it did, I think that AMECON is fairly well tied down, much more than I have ever known in the case of a government contract of this kind. While I cannot here rule out that there will ever be a cost increase, I do not believe that it is possible for any massive cost increase to occur, because of the very detailed cost control system that we have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I genuinely appreciate the way in which the Minister has handled this matter. I have one last question on the subject. I am advised that the other area of financial risk, if there is one, is in the area of integrated logistic support (ILS), including spares, training and so on.
