TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter brought to my attention today by a community nurse in Canberra. I think it is simplest and quickest to read what she said:

SPEECH.PARA: It was very interesting to see that the Minister for Industrial Relations recently ``welcomed a 3% pay rise for public servants'' . . . Meanwhile his colleague the Minister for Veterans' Affairs was quietly preparing to implement what amounts to an effective pay cut of 18% for part time nurses who provide home nursing services to ageing veterans.

It's being done so quietly that it took two days of intensive telephone inquiry with the Minister's office and his Department at the most senior levels to find anyone who could or would explain the cut to me. The cut was first made known through a Domiciliary Nursing Circular dated 1 September which stated in rather vague terms that ``home visit travel by providers [are they frightened to call us Nurses?] in their local area will no longer be reimbursed''.

We nurses work as casuals earning about $18.00 for a one hour home visit, plus mileage allowance of about 40 cents a kilometre up to 16 kilometres for using our own cars (travelling time of 35 to 45 minutes is unpaid and unlike the States, Veterans' Affairs won't provide cars). As a cost cutting measure the Minister has decreed that the first ten kilometres of travel will be unpaid. On top of the limit of 16 kilometres already imposed, this means that the maximum contribution of the Government to our very considerable transport costs will be a miserable allowance for six kilometres. I wonder how many public servants would be willing to use their own cars on Government business under such terms and conditions?

In response to my telephone inquiry, I was told that our rates of pay actually include a component for travel. This is sheer nonsense. No matter how they try to disguise it the bare facts are that our income will be cut by about $4.00 for each visit. At $18.00 for a one hour visit (with no sick pay, annual leave, paid travelling time, workers compensation or professional indemnity), there is no proposal for any compensating increase. A cut in income of $4.00 may not sound much, but it means a cut of $40 to $60 out of a total income of $220 to $330 per week.

It is a hard hitting move by the Minister and his (predominantly male) bureaucrats against a group of caring and dedicated women-women who are generally forced to accept part time work for many different reasons. So much for the Labor Government's concern for social justice, especially for the plight of women. We will be forced to take a massive cut in income but we are a group who can least afford it!

The pity of it all is that it is the old veterans who will suffer in the end because the Government will find it increasingly hard to find trained nurses who are willing to accept the penny-pinching approach of the Minister and his Department.

The fact is, of course, that these women have had a hard time from the Department of Veterans' Affairs for a very long time. It was not so long ago that, on many occasions, I had to chase the Department for weeks to get the payment that was due to the nurses for the work they were doing. It is an unconscionable act on the part of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) and his Department to seek to make ends meet by cutting some of the most vulnerable employees within the Department. As the nurse who brought this matter to my attention has pointed out, it is the veterans who will suffer in the end. If costs need to be cut there must be other ways of doing it than picking on the domiciliary nursing service in the fashion that I have just read out from this letter. I have a copy of the document that has been referred to, which states:

When itemising a visit only that time during which a patient is receiving active attention is to be counted. The time taken by a domiciliary nurse to travel to a patient's home is not to be taken into consideration in the determination of the length of the visit. Fees are payable only in respect of the time a patient is receiving active attention.

I point out that the rate of pay is $18 per hour, which is not a very handsome rate. This seems to me to be attacking the most vulnerable group, and I think the Minister should be thoroughly ashamed of himself for allowing it to happen. I ask the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds), who is in the chamber, whether she will take the matter up with the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and point out exactly how harshly either he or his Department is treating these particular nurses, who provide a great service.

The Minister might also stop to think about what it would cost to have even one of these veterans admitted to hospital to be looked after. What would that cost to run? Yet the Department cuts down on the domiciliary service. If the Minister thinks that is good management of Veterans' Affairs, I suggest that he look at it again. I can assure him that the cost of having even one veteran admitted to a hospital would be a great deal more, and it could happen, because we do not have sufficient domiciliary nurses prepared to work for the pittance they are now to be paid. The rest of us will be paying a great deal more to maintain a veteran in a hospital rather than in his own home.

TALK.START.PARA: —The decision to abolish the entitlement to travel allowances for home visits was made in the last Budget. TALK.START.PARA: —There is one other matter I wish to raise, which I will leave to be responded to at some other time. I do not require it during the time that we are looking into this Department. I will accept a reply in due course and take such action as is necessary if that does not happen. The Minister will no doubt remember that the Government transferred arrangements for defence service home loans from the Defence Service Homes Corporation to Westpac Banking Corporation. Much of the literature put out at the time indicated that those people who were purchasing their homes through the Corporation would not pay more under the new arrangements. I refer to two documents. The first is headed `Defence Service Home Loan Changes'. It is a printed document with a drawing of a house in the middle. It states in part:

SPEECH.PARA: For existing DSH borrowers the present terms and conditions remain unchanged, however payments are now made at a Westpac branch.
The other document is a letter, sent presumably to all purchasers through the scheme, from the Defence Service Homes Corporation which states in part:
The interest rate on your loan will not change and your monthly repayments will not increase.
To an extent, that is true. It also states:
. . . purchasers will continue to enjoy the same loan terms as at present.

If one looks at a statement of account of any purchaser under the Corporation, it clearly stated the principal amount and the deductions made each month; no other charges were levied against the account. But, if one looks at the Westpac account which is now sent to each purchaser, it is clear that there is a deduction made for a government duty on deposits-a deduction that it would seem is made every two months. That is a charge which was not borne by those purchasing through the Defence Service Homes Corporation prior to the change that the Government made transferring the arrangements to Westpac. In paying the money to Westpac, a bank account is established in the name of the purchaser and, according to the correspondence from Westpac, it then has no choice but to pay the government charge on that account as would be the case on any other bank account with Westpac. There is no way around it. To pay cash does not help because an account is still established in the name of the purchaser. It may be said that the amount that has to be paid under this financial institutions duty is not very much. That may be the case, but it still means that all purchasers are paying a charge that they were not paying previously, which is in contravention of all the literature that was sent out to purchasers prior to the change and which said that they would enjoy the same loan terms and that the terms and conditions would remain unchanged.

I guess the question is: Will the Government make arrangements so that these accounts with Westpac are not debited with this charge and for the charges that have already been debited to be refunded? Of course, what will happen eventually is that these people will not be paying off their mortgage in the way they thought because the debt will be growing each two months by the amount of duty being deducted from the account. So the monthly repayment will not meet the commitment that the purchasers thought they were meeting under the agreement.

I will read a letter from a constituent which cites the anomaly that seems to concern quite a number of totally and permanently incapacitated pensioners who are concerned about the situation when eventually their wives will become war widows by virtue of their passing. I will read directly from a constituent's letter recently received. He states:

SPEECH.PARA: I am writing to draw your attention to a serious anomaly which has developed with regard to War Widows.
I am a totally and permanently incapacitated veteran and on my death my wife will automatically become a War Widow.

He then refers to an article which appeared in a publication called Age Pension News, Issue No. 2. Unfortunately, I do not have the date of that publication because it is not shown on the copy of this article. The article under the heading `Extra Security for the bereaved' cites the generous provision of bereavement allowances contained in the Budget. But there is an anomaly which suggests that that generosity will not, in fact, be extended to war widows who find themselves disadvantaged relative to ordinary pensioners who receive these benefits. The constituent goes on to state:

On reading a copy of Issue 2 of Age Pension News. . . I found that from next January a widow of an age pensioner would receive after her husband's death, and over the next seven paydays, the total amount that would otherwise have been received by the couple. It was pointed out that this could amount to $1247.
The article in the Age Pension News sees that as a very positive and a quite generous provision for the bereaved. The letter states:

I twice contacted Veterans' Affairs, and once Department of Social Security inquiring about the situation with regard to War Widows and was told on each occasion that the information available to them indicated that War Widows would only receive the $550 funeral allowance currently available to them.
This is a savage discrimination against War Widows and can only be the result of some stupid mistake or omission.
I would greatly appreciate your looking into this matter . . .

My question to the Minister is therefore: Is this an anomaly or is it perhaps a misunderstanding by the author of the article, which has been compounded by a misunderstanding by the author of this letter? However, it is an anomaly which has been drawn to my attention by several other veterans.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 10 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to an article in the Weekend Australian of 19-20 August 1989 headed `Budding export market for the seeds of our native trees', what was the volume in financial terms of exports of Australian native tree seeds in the financial years 1986-87, 1987-88, and, if available, 1988-89.
(2) What is the projected value of this export industry in the current financial year, and what are the estimates for the long-term future.
(3) Which varieties of Australian trees are being exported, and where are Australia's main markets.
(4) What marketing and promotional schemes are currently in place or projected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) There are no specific statistics regarding exports of Australian native tree seeds. The figure of $7 million per annum quoted by Stephen Midgley in the Weekend Australian is an informal estimate given by the Australian Tree Seed Centre (CSIRO) and compiled after enquiries to the major exporters. The Australian Bureau of Statistics does not distinguish Australian Native tree seeds from others in its figures.

The industry could grow significantly especially if it moved seriously into the production of improved seed. The demand for Australian eucalypt seed far exceeds the supply and there is potential for the establishment of seed orchards specifically for this purpose utilising available expertise in genetic resources and breeding strategy.

(3) The main varieties exported are Eucalyptus, Acacia and Casuarina but other genera such as Grevillea and Melaleuca are receiving increased attention. The main markets for native tree seeds are South Africa, Spain, Portugal, Uruguay, Brazil, Argentina, Chile and South-East Asia.

(4) At present commercial seed companies have no difficulty in procuring markets. The Australian Tree Seed Centre of the CSIRO collaborates with Australian and international research institutions, development assistance agencies and companies in the provision of certified seed and specialised services. Consultation with commercial seed operators has indicated that due to the level of demand there is great scope for further collection and production. There is no formal marketing and promotion effort by the Government.
